It is the fourth year running that the zoo has been the most popular paid-for attraction.</p> <p>The zoo enjoyed record visitor figures with the last four months of 2014 all being record-breakers. January and February this year have continued the theme smashing previous visitor records.</p> <p>Chester Zoo&rsquo;s managing director, Jamie Christon, said:&nbsp;</p> <blockquote> <p>2014 ended on a real high with the busiest year in our history and we&rsquo;re off to a flying start in 2015. Time and again the zoo excels in delivering a great day out for its visitors.</p> <p>This year is a ground-breaking year for the zoo too with the opening of our new development Islands. It&rsquo;s the biggest zoo development of its kind in Europe providing a window on the world of conservation in South East Asia.</p> </blockquote> <p><a href="/islands">Islands</a>, which opens in June, will recreate habitats from six areas in South East Asia - Panay, Papua, Bali, Sumatra, Sumba and Sulawesi - and provide a home for a number of animals classed as critically endangered in the wild, including Sumatran tigers, Sumatran orangutans and Visayan warty pigs.</p> <p>Jamie added:</p> <blockquote> <p>Islands will drive visitor figures up even further and bring the zoo to a whole new audience. We couldn&rsquo;t be more pleased with where we are at today and have a lot to look forward to this year.</p> </blockquote> <p><br /> </p> <h2>About Islands at Chester Zoo</h2> <ul>     <li> Islands is the biggest and most ambitious zoo project in UK history </li>     <li> Work began in August 2013 </li>     <li> It is set to open in June 2015 </li>     <li> It is currently one of the biggest construction sites in the UK </li>     <li> Visitors will move through recreations of habitats from Panay, Papua, Bali, Sumatra, Sumba and Sulawesi, walking through different levels, travelling in boats and seeing buildings just like the real thing. It will create the feeling of an expedition and make visitors feel like they&rsquo;re following in the footsteps of the great explorers </li>     <li> The Lazy River Boat Journey will feature 14 boats, carrying 238 visitors at any one time, on a 15-minute-long trip&nbsp; </li>     <li> 42,000 plants will be used to recreate the environments of the six different islands </li>     <li> The flagship indoor building that will be part of Islands will be called the Monsoon Forest &ndash; the largest indoor zoo exhibit in the UK. It will be totally unique in this country and will feature free flight birds, Sumatran orangutans, macaques and Sunda gharial crocodiles </li>     <li> Other animals include anoa, banteng, babirusa, Bali starling, cassowary, Indonesian wrinkled hornbill, lorikeet, Sumatran tiger and the Visayan warty pig </li>     <li> The zoo hopes that by showcasing animals like this then visitors seeing animals in an even more naturalistic setting than ever before will make more of an emotional connection with them. If people care about a species they&rsquo;re more likely to help save them </li>     <li> Website: <a href="http://www.chesterzoo.org/islands">www.chesterzoo.org/islands</a> </li> </ul></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 10:13:13 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{C3B70D69-FC7A-4A1B-87D9-B845677C31F4}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/rare-indonesian-piglet-born</link><title>Rare Indonesian piglet born at Chester Zoo</title><description><p>One of the rarest piglets in the world is set to make her debut at Chester Zoo.</p><p>The baby babirusa, named Matano by zookeepers, was born to mum Majene following a 161-day pregnancy.</p> <p>Babirusa are native to the Indonesian island of Sulawesi where their numbers are in serious decline due to habitat loss through logging and hunting for their meat.</p> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Babirusa piglet Matano" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/hoofed-animals/babirusa/Babirusa piglet Matano (9).ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p>Chester Zoo is one of only a handful of zoos in the whole of Europe which has successfully bred the distinctive animals and the arrival of Matano is therefore being heralded as  important for the future of the species.  </p> <p>Curator of mammals, Tim Rowlands, said:</p> <blockquote> <p> Babirusa pigs are highly threatened. They&rsquo;re one of the rarest pig species on the planet and so our new little arrival is a significant addition to the world&rsquo;s population.</p> <p> Years of planning and preparation have gone into us being able to successfully breed babirusa here. Matano is important for the future of the species and so we&rsquo;re thrilled to bits with her. </p> <p> We hope that, one day, Matano will grow up to become a vital part of the international breeding programme which is working to safeguard the species by ensuring there&rsquo;s a healthy, viable back-up population in the event that they disappear from the wild.     </p> </blockquote> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Babirusa piglet Matano - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/hoofed-animals/babirusa/Babirusa piglet Matano (10).ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p>Matano was born in early December and, in the weeks and months since, keepers have kept a watchful eye on her and mum in a special behind-the-scenes area.</p> <p>Now, however, the proud mum and playful youngster are ready to make their first public appearances.    </p> <p>Mr Rowlands added:</p> <blockquote> <p> Babirusa are a sensitive species and we needed to give mum and baby plenty of quiet time to bond. Majene is a great, experienced mother &ndash; very protective and extremely watchful over her piglet. Little Matano doesn&rsquo;t leave her side. </p> </blockquote> <p>Some of the zoo&rsquo;s five babirusa will move to a brand new exhibit when Islands, the biggest and most ambitious expansion project in UK zoo history, opens in June.  </p> <p>Islands will recreate habitats in the Philippines, Bali, Sulawesi, Papua, Sumba and Sumatra and see visitors set off on their own conservation expedition. </p> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Babirusa piglet Matano at Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/hoofed-animals/babirusa/Babirusa piglet Matano (8).ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <h2>Babirusa facts </h2> <ul>     <li> Babirusa piglet Matano was born on 2/12/2014, following a 161 day pregnancy for her mum, Majene </li>     <li> Dad is called Sausu   </li>     <li> Chester Zoo is one of only a handful of zoos in the whole of Europe which has successfully bred the distinctive animals </li>     <li> The species is endemic to the Sulawesi rainforests of Indonesia </li>     <li> Babirusa are highly threatened and one of the rarest pig species on the planet </li>     <li> They are classed by conservationists as vulnerable to extinction in the wild </li>     <li> In the wild, the species has seen numbers plummet largely because of habitat loss through logging and hunting for their meat </li>     <li> They are members of the pig family but in Indonesia the name babirusa means pig deer after their unusual appearance, especially the males with their big curling tusks </li>     <li> Babirusa feed on fruit, seeds, nuts, insects and fungi </li>     <li> In June 2015, the zoo&rsquo;s babirusa will move to a brand new exhibit when Islands, the biggest development in UK zoo history, opens. Islands will recreate habitats from Panay, Papua, Bali, Sumatra, Sumba and Sulawesi and showcase species such Sumatran orangutans, cassowary, Sumatran tigers and Sunda gharial crocodiles, as well as babirusa. Unlike anything else in the UK, it will show animals in an even more naturalistic setting than ever before, which the zoo hopes will see visitors make more of an emotional connection with them. If people care about a species they&rsquo;re more likely to help save them </li>     <li> Website: <a href="http://www.chesterzoo.org/islands">www.chesterzoo.org/islands</a> </li> </ul></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:02 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{669CC0B5-691E-4A3F-93E6-42AD86FE770C}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/baby-black-rhino-2015</link><title>Caught on camera: The amazing moment a baby black rhino arrives into the world at Chester Zoo</title><description><p>The amazing moment a rhino gives birth has been caught on camera at Chester Zoo. </p><div class="video">   <iframe frameborder="0" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/xcyZXelMHqI?rel=0"> </iframe> <div class="video-mask video-mask__top"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__right"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__bottom"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__left"></div> </div> <p>The 50-second footage shows mum deliver her newborn and the tender first moments as she checks over her calf.</p> <p>Born on Jan 31 at 08:15, the female calf, which keepers have named <em>Fara</em>, is the offspring of 17-year-old <em>Kitani</em> and 15-year-old dad, <em>Sammy</em>.</p> <p><em>Sammy&rsquo;s</em> genes are extremely valuable part of the European Endangered Species Breeding Programme for the critically endangered animals.</p> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Baby rhino with mum" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/horses-and-rhinos/black-rhino/calf/Baby black rhino born at Chester Zoo (1).ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p>Curator of mammals at Chester Zoo, Tim Rowlands, said:</p> <blockquote> <p><em>Kitani&rsquo;s</em> delivery was textbook. We got a &lsquo;maternity suite&rsquo; ready for her with deep sandy floors and beds of hay but ultimately she chose her own spot.</p> <p>The footage has enabled us to witness this really special moment and both mum and youngster are doing really, really well. </p> <p>Every birth is cause for great celebration but given that Eastern black rhino face a real threat of extinction our new arrival is even more significant. The calf is super important to the breeding programme in Europe and her arrival is another step towards sustaining a black rhino population which, in the wild, is being ravaged by poachers on an almost daily basis.</p> </blockquote> <p>In the wild there are thought to be less than 650 Eastern black rhinos remaining, pushing the species perilously close to extinction.</p> <p>Numbers in Africa are plummeting as a result of a dramatic surge in illegal poaching, fuelled by a global increase in demand for rhino horn to supply the traditional Asian medicine market. </p> <p>The problem is being driven by the astonishing street value of rhino horn, which is currently worth more per gram than gold and cocaine.</p> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Baby rhino born at Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/horses-and-rhinos/black-rhino/calf/DTrhino7.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p>Mr Rowlands added:</p> <blockquote> <p>We put great effort into protecting black rhinos in the wild, supporting a number of sanctuaries across Africa. However, as the demand for rhino horn intensifies, poaching continues to become a bigger and bigger problem. </p> <p>We hope that, one day, we can put an end to this crisis once and for all. But in the meantime we need to ensure we have an insurance population and that&rsquo;s why this arrival is such brilliant news. This means there&rsquo;s a very happy team of keepers, vets and conservationists here at Chester Zoo today.</p> <p>All being well, <em>Fara</em> will also one day play her own breeding role in a programme, which, in some cases, has already seen some black rhinos return to Africa to help boost numbers. </p> <p>For the time being though she is forging very important early bonds with mum.</p> </blockquote> <p>The calf is the latest in a long-line of arrivals at the zoo in the last two years, following <em>Chanua</em>, <em>Dakima</em> and <em>Embu</em>. She brings the total number of Eastern black rhinos at the zoo to 11.</p> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Baby rhino with mum at Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/horses-and-rhinos/black-rhino/calf/DTrhino6.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Baby rhino at Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/horses-and-rhinos/black-rhino/calf/DTrhino5.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <h2>Black rhino notes</h2> <ul>     <li>Kitani was born at Chester Zoo on 16/06/1997. She is 17-years-old</li>     <li>Dad Sammy, 15, moved to Chester Zoo from Osaka in Japan in 2002. He currently lives at Port Lympne</li>     <li>The female calf, which keepers have named Fara, is a second for Kitani who had Asani in 2008 </li>     <li>Eastern black rhinos are listed as critically endangered by the International Union for the conservation of Nature (IUCN)</li>     <li>The number of black rhinos in Kenya plummeted from about 20,000 in 1970 to 597 (as at December 2010) </li>     <li>Chester Zoo is one of the main organisations fighting for the survival of eastern black rhino and has long supported conservation efforts in the wild to try and protect black rhinos and continues to pump money, and provide expertise, to numerous sanctuaries in Africa</li>     <li>The Chester ZooBlack Rhino Programmestarted in1999, in partnership with Save the Rhino, providing substantial financial support to Kenya Wildlife Service to enable the translocation of 20 black rhinos to wildlife reserves in the Tsavo region of Kenya</li>     <li>More recently we have also provided support for the rhinos in Chyula Hills National Park and Laikipia District in Kenya and Mkomazi in Tanzania</li>     <li>Helping to ensure an insurance population exists in the event that black rhino become extinct in the wild; Chester Zoo has been successful in breeding a number of critically endangered black rhinos and plays a vital part in the international breeding programme</li>     <li>Ground-breaking science by a team at Chester Zoo team has contributed to the zoo&rsquo;s successful black rhino breeding programme. Zoo researchers have spent several years carefully monitoring the hormone levels of their resident female rhinos in a bid to discover the best time to introduce them to a potential partner. These hormone levels are monitored by analysing rhino dung. Tracking hormones gives an insight into what is going on inside the animals. It can help tell things like whether or not an animal is a seasonal breeder, whether it has reached puberty, whether it&rsquo;s cycling on a regular basis or not and when the optimum time to introduce a male to a female is, as well as diagnose pregnancies and estimate when an animal will give birth.</li> </ul></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:02 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{43B07126-0B1E-4B3A-9FE2-BA455BD17027}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/truckloads-south-east-asian-artefacts</link><title>Truckloads of South East Asian artefacts arrive at Chester Zoo</title><description><p>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdTreasure trove\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd of long boats, tuk-tuks and market stalls unloaded ahead of opening of biggest ever UK zoo development</p><figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Islands artefacts being loaded" src="/~/media/news/2015/islands-artefacts/IMG_0127.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p>Hundreds of original South East Asian artefacts &ndash; including long boats and tuk-tuks &ndash; have arrived at Chester Zoo.</p> <p>Canoes, stall frontages, ploughs, mopeds and tools, sourced from all over South East Asia, are amongst the items to have been shipped from ports in Indonesia as the zoo prepares to unveil its new &pound;30m Islands development in June.</p> <p>Islands, billed as the biggest building project in UK zoo history, will recreate habitats from Panay, Papua, Bali, Sumatra, Sumba and Sulawesi.</p> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Tuk tuk " src="/~/media/news/2015/WP_20150204_11_12_17_Pro.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure><figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Dr Maggie Esson and Kim Halliday" src="/~/media/news/2015/islands-artefacts/IslandsShipment1-63.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p>Education programmes manager at Chester Zoo, Dr Maggie Esson, said:</p> <blockquote> <p>This is a home delivery unlike any other. It&rsquo;s a very special shopping list indeed - a real treasure trove of unusual bits and pieces all the way from South East Asia.</p> <p>All of these amazing artefacts are destined for our new zone, Islands, which is about transporting people to another place &ndash; making them feel like, for a few hours at least, they&rsquo;ve stepped into South East Asia and are exploring that most incredible part of the planet. </p> <p>We&rsquo;re making it as authentic as we possibly can and that&rsquo;s why we&rsquo;ve done our shopping in places like Indonesia. As well as the animals, the landscaping and the architecture, it&rsquo;s all of these details that will bring the place alive and create a truly authentic snapshot of the region.</p> <p>The genuine old boats, tools, market stalls, fabrics and tuk-tuks will help us to tell the stories of what happens on these remarkable islands, including our vital field conservation work.</p> </blockquote> <p>A host of items, including three, three-tonne boats, were purchased directly from families in South East Asia. </p> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Longboat for Islands" src="/~/media/news/2015/islands-artefacts/IslandsShipment1-60.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p>Dr Esson added:</p> <blockquote> <p>Many of these items have a fascinating back-story. The boats, for example, used to belong to fishermen from Java in Indonesia. They&rsquo;d use the boats daily, in good weather, fishing for skipjack, yellow fin tuna, snapper, king mackerel and sardines.</p> <p>With the money they&rsquo;ve received for the boats they&rsquo;ve now been able to buy better replacements to help improve the size of their catch and help them earn a better wage.</p> </blockquote> <p>Islands will provide a home for a number of animals classed as critically endangered in the wild, including Sumatran tigers, Sumatran orangutans and Visayan warty pigs as well as over 50 other species.</p> <h2>About Islands at Chester Zoo</h2> <ul>     <li>Islands is a &pound;30 million development project - the biggest and most ambitious zoo project in UK history</li>     <li>Work on Islands began in August 2013</li>     <li>It is set to open in June 2015</li>     <li>Currently one of the biggest construction sites in the UK</li>     <li>Visitors will move through recreations of habitats from Panay, Papua, Bali, Sumatra, Sumba and Sulawesi, walking through different levels, travelling in boats and seeing buildings just like the real thing. It will create the feeling of an expedition and make visitors feel like they&rsquo;re following in the footsteps of the great explorers</li>     <li>42,000 plants be used to recreate the environments of the six different islands</li>     <li>The flagship indoor building that will be part of Islands will be called the Monsoon Forest &ndash; the largest indoor zoo exhibit in the UK. It will be totally unique in this country and will feature free flight birds, Sumatran orangutans, macaques and crocodiles</li>     <li>Other animals include anoa, banteng, babirusa, Bali starling, cassowary, Indonesian rhinoceros hornbill, Indonesian wrinkled hornbill, lorikeet, Sumatran tiger and the Visayan warty pig</li>     <li>The zoo hopes that by showcasing animals like this, then visitors seeing animals in an even more naturalistic setting than ever before, will make more of an emotional connection with them. If people care about a species they&rsquo;re more likely to help save them</li>     <li>Website: <a href="http://www.chesterzoo.org/islands" style="line-height: 1.3;">www.chesterzoo.org/islands</a></li> </ul></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:02 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{E7B1985C-F805-4610-8265-691739DE1A24}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/tiger-cub-triplets-photos</link><title>Pictured: The moment three of the world\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds rarest tiger cubs took their first steps outside</title><description><p>Rare Sumatran tiger triplets have begun to emerge from their den at Chester Zoo </p><figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Tiger cub triplets at Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2015/tiger-cubs/tiger 16 pb.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p>A trio of tiny Sumatran tiger cubs have made their first public appearances at Chester Zoo.</p> <p>The three-week-old tiger triplets were born on Jan 2 but have just started to emerge from their den as their proud mum starts to show them off.</p> <div class="video">   <iframe frameborder="0" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/3K_LWb9OtOc?rel=0"> </iframe> <div class="video-mask video-mask__top"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__right"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__bottom"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__left"></div> </div> <p>The cubs are the off-spring of eight-year-old Sumatran tigress Kirana and seven-year-old dad Fabi.</p> <p>There are believed to be just 300-400 Sumatran tigers left in the wild as they are often targeted by poachers who use their body parts as traditional medicine and much of their jungle habitat has been destroyed.</p> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Two tiger cubs - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2015/tiger-cubs/tiger 9 pb.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure>  <p>Curator of mammals, Tim Rowlands, said:</p> <blockquote> <p>Sumatran tigers are one of the rarest big cat species in the world. That&rsquo;s what makes our new tiger trio so incredibly special &ndash; they&rsquo;re a rare boost to an animal that&rsquo;s critically endangered.</p> <p>It&rsquo;s still early days but Kirana is an experienced mum and she&rsquo;s keeping her cubs very well protected. She&rsquo;s doing everything we would hope at this stage.</p> </blockquote> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Tiger cub - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2015/tiger-cubs/Tigers-8.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="tiger cub with mum at Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2015/tiger-cubs/Tigers-14.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p>Sumatran tigers are found only on the Indonesian islands of Sumatra. They are the smallest of all tigers and also have the narrowest stripes.</p> <p>Mr Rowlands added:</p> <blockquote> <p>The arrival of this latest trio of cubs is vital to the ongoing survival of the species and the back-up population found in zoos. They are now part of a safety-net against the population in the wild becoming extinct which, to me, is incredibly humbling.</p> </blockquote> <p>It will be several weeks until keepers can discover the sexes of the tiger triplets and a decision can be made on their names.</p> <h2>Sumatran tiger facts</h2> <ul>     <li>The trio of cubs at Chester Zoo were born on Jan 2, 2015</li>     <li>Mum Kirana is eight-years-old</li>     <li>Dad Fabi is seven</li>     <li>Kirana and Fabi&rsquo;s last cubs, Kasih and Nuri, are also at Chester Zoo</li>     <li>Sumatran tigers are found in patches of forest on the island of Sumatra in Indonesia</li>     <li>The species is classed by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) as critically endangered in the wild. They are faced with a high threat of extinction due to widespread habitat loss and poaching for their body parts which are used in traditional medicine</li>     <li>Sumatran tigers are the smallest of all tiger species</li>     <li>Sumatran tigers are narrower and closer together than those of all other tiger species</li>     <li>Chester Zoo&rsquo;s Sumatran tigers are part of the European Endangered Species Breeding Programme. The zoo works closely with other zoos on conservation breeding projects to try and ensure the ongoing survival of the species</li>     <li>In June 2015, the zoo&rsquo;s tigers will move to a brand new exhibit when Islands, the biggest development in UK zoo history, opens. Islands will recreate habitats from Panay, Papua, Bali, Sumatra, Sumba and Sulawesi and showcase species such Sumatran orangutans, cassowary and Sunda gharial crocodiles, as well as Sumatran tigers. Unlike anything else in the UK, it will show animals in an even more naturalistic setting than ever before, which the zoo hopes will see visitors make more of an emotional connection with them. If people care about a species they&rsquo;re more likely to help save them</li>     <li>Website: <a href="http://www.chesterzoo.org/islands">www.chesterzoo.org/islands</a></li> </ul></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:02 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{1369D4E9-ED55-4C14-9991-44E218FB1053}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/tiger-cub-triplets</link><title>CCTV records early moments of rare tiger triplets at Chester Zoo</title><description><p>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdIncredibly special\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Sumatran tiger trio born</p><figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Tiger cubs on cctv at Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2015/tigers-cctv.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <figcaption>FIRST GLIMPSE: Chester Zoo has released footage of three rare Sumatran tiger cubs, born on Friday Jan 2.</figcaption> </figure> <p>Hidden cameras have captured some of the first moments of three rare tiger cubs at Chester Zoo.</p> <p>The tigers were born to eight-year-old Sumatran tigress Kirana on Jan 2 after a 105-day pregnancy.</p> <p>Curator of mammals at Chester Zoo, Tim Rowlands, said:</p> <blockquote> <p>We&rsquo;re thrilled to kick off 2015 with these special arrivals. These tiny triplets who, in June, will move to a brand new home in our Islands zone, are now part of a safety-net against the population in the wild becoming extinct. That to me is incredibly humbling.</p> </blockquote> <p>The sexes of the cubs will not be known for some time and zoo staff are continuing to keep a close eye on the family.</p> <div class="video">   <iframe frameborder="0" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/HZfyBmYO7q4?rel=0"> </iframe> <div class="video-mask video-mask__top"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__right"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__bottom"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__left"></div> </div> <p>Mr Rowlands added:</p> <blockquote> <p>We had Kirana&rsquo;s due date down as Friday Jan 2 and, true to what we thought, she had her cubs  in the early hours of that morning. We were first alerted to them when we heard tiny squeaks coming from their den. Initially we weren&rsquo;t sure of how many she had had &ndash; we just kept seeing flashes of tiny balls of fluff &ndash; but we&rsquo;ve since spotted that there are three.</p> <p>It&rsquo;s still early days but Kirana is an experienced mum and she&rsquo;s keeping her cubs very well protected. She&rsquo;s doing everything we would hope at this stage.</p> <p>Sumatran tigers are one of the rarest big cat species in the world. That&rsquo;s what makes our new tiger trio so incredibly special &ndash; they&rsquo;re a rare boost to an animal that&rsquo;s critically endangered.</p> </blockquote> <p>Sumatran tigers are found only on the Indonesian islands of Sumatra. They are the smallest of all tigers and also have the narrowest stripes.</p> <p>With numbers in the wild believed to be as few as just 300-400, Sumatran tigers are classed by conservationists as critically endangered. They are targeted by poachers who use their body parts as traditional medicine and much of their jungle habitat has been destroyed. The arrival of this latest trio of cubs is therefore vital to the ongoing survival of the species and the back-up population found in zoos.</p> <h2>Sumatran tiger facts</h2> <ul>     <li>The trio of cubs at Chester Zoo were born on Jan 2, 2015</li>     <li>Mum Kirana is eight-years-old</li>     <li>Dad Fabi is seven</li>     <li>Kirana and Fabi&rsquo;s last cubs, Kasih and Nuri, are also at Chester Zoo</li>     <li>Sumatran tigers are found in patches of forest on the island of Sumatra in Indonesia</li>     <li>The species is classed by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) as critically endangered in the wild. They are faced with a high threat of extinction due to widespread habitat loss and poaching for their body parts which are used in traditional medicine</li>     <li>Sumatran tigers are the smallest of all tiger species</li>     <li>Sumatran tigers are narrower and closer together than those of all other tiger species</li>     <li>Chester Zoo&rsquo;s Sumatran tigers are part of the European Endangered Species Breeding Programme. The zoo works closely with other zoos on conservation breeding projects to try and ensure the ongoing survival of the species</li>     <li>In June 2015, the zoo&rsquo;s tigers will move to a brand new exhibit when Islands, the biggest development in UK zoo history, opens. Islands will recreate habitats from Panay, Papua, Bali, Sumatra, Sumba and Sulawesi and showcase species such Sumatran orangutans, cassowary and Sunda gharial crocodiles, as well as Sumatran tigers. Unlike anything else in the UK, it will show animals in an even more naturalistic setting than ever before, which the zoo hopes will see visitors make more of an emotional connection with them. If people care about a species they&rsquo;re more likely to help save them</li>     <li>Website: www.chesterzoo.org/islands</li> </ul></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:02 long legs at Chester Zoo!</title><description><p>A rare baby giraffe is walking tall at Chester Zoo. </p><figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Baby giraffe" src="/~/media/news/2015/BabyGiraffe-46.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p>The 6ft (1.8m) calf, which keepers have named Zahra, was born just before Christmas.</p> <p>Now, at just two-weeks-old, she has taken her first steps outside, alongside mum Aoife, dad Meru and rest of the herd.&nbsp;</p> <p>Curator of mammals at Chester Zoo, Tim Rowlands, said:</p> <blockquote> <p>Not-so-little Zahra is already confident on her long legs.</p> </blockquote> <p>Rothschild&rsquo;s are one of the world&rsquo;s most endangered subspecies of giraffe, with recent estimates suggesting less than 1,100 are left in the wild.</p> <p>Once wide-ranging across Kenya, Uganda and Sudan, the species has been almost totally eliminated from much of its former range and now only survives in a few small, isolated populations in Kenya and Uganda. Their main threats come from loss of habitat and poaching for meat and hides.</p> <p>On top of its successful breeding record, Chester Zoo has supported important projects in the wild, including the first ever scientific review of the Rothschild&rsquo;s giraffe. Its aim is to develop a long-term conservation strategy for the species in Africa.</p> <h2>Rothschild&rsquo;s giraffe facts</h2> <ul>     <li>Mum Aoife was born on 1 March 1998. She is 16 years old</li>     <li>Dad is called Meru</li>     <li>The baby &ndash; a female named Zahra - was born at around 3am on Dec 23. She is Aoife&rsquo;s second calf. Zahra means &lsquo;flower&rsquo; in Swahili</li>     <li>Rothschild&rsquo;s giraffe are named after zoologist Lord Walter Rothschild, founder of the National History Museum in Tring, Hertfordshire</li>     <li>They are also known as the baringo or Ugandan giraffe</li>     <li>The species is identified by its broader dividing white lines and has no spots beneath the knees</li>     <li>Giraffe population figures are declining across Africa</li>     <li>Rothschild&rsquo;s  giraffes are classed as endangered by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) with current population estimates suggesting less than 1,100 remain in the wild</li>     <li>With less than 1,100 individuals remaining in the wild the Rothschild's giraffe is more endangered than species such as African elephants and giant pandas</li>     <li>Roughly one-third of the surviving population of Rothschild&rsquo;s giraffes live in zoos where carefully co-ordinated breeding programmes are creating a safety-net population for the species</li>     <li>Once wide-ranging across Kenya, Uganda and Sudan, the Rothschild&rsquo;s giraffe has been almost totally eliminated from much of its former range and now only survives in a few small, isolated populations in Kenya and Uganda</li>     <li>The main threat to the species now is loss of habitat and poaching for meat and hides</li>     <li>In the past, giraffes were hunted for their tails, which were used as good-luck charms, sewing thread and even fly swats</li>     <li>The species is one of the most endangered of the nine sub-species of giraffe</li>     <li>Chester Zoo now has eight Rothschild giraffes &ndash; Meru, Aoife, Dagma, Orla, Tula, Kanzi, Millie and Zahra&nbsp;</li> </ul></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:02 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{B86F2564-4E0A-4035-89EC-10C6B260B4A9}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/record-breaking-visitor-figures</link><title>Chester Zoo celebrates record-breaking 2014</title><description><p>Chester Zoo achieved its busiest year of all-time in 2014.</p><figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Baby giraffe Zahra" src="/~/media/news/2015/Baby giraffe Zahra Custom.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <figcaption>STANDING PROUD: After achieving its busiest year of all time in 2014, new arrivals such as Rothschild giraffe Zahra have seen visitor numbers to Chester Zoo get off to a strong start in 2015.</figcaption> </figure> <p>Visitor numbers to the UK&rsquo;s most popular zoo reached 1,432,867 &ndash; the highest in its 84 year history.</p> <p>Membership also hit record levels at 57,835, up 7,827 on the previous year and 1,507 animal adoptions were taken out in December &ndash; the most ever for a single month, smashing the previous best of 1,185 in 2009.</p> <p>The figures come after the zoo was named as the best in the UK by users of travel website TripAdvisor.</p> <p>Managing director Jamie Christon said:</p> <blockquote> <p>We&rsquo;re thrilled that the zoo attracted such a huge amount of interest - locally, nationally and internationally - in 2014 , the highest visitor numbers in our history. As a conservation and education charity we very much rely on visitors to help fund the great work we do to protect species around the world and so our heartfelt thanks go to each and every person that has come here and supported us.</p> <p>The zoo is constantly evolving and looking to offer new and exciting experiences and with what we have in store later this year, we&rsquo;re confident we&rsquo;ll have even more to wow people with.</p> </blockquote> <p>Staff at the zoo hope the impressive numbers will be bettered again when its new &pound;30m Islands development opens later this year.</p> <p><em><a href="/islands">Islands</a></em>, the biggest expansion in UK zoo history, will recreate habitats from the Philippines, Bali, Sulawesi, Papua, Sumba and Sumatra and showcase species such as Sumatran tigers, Sumatran orangutans, cassowary and Sunda gharial crocodiles.</p> <p>Jamie added:</p> <blockquote> <p><em>Islands</em> is incredibly ambitious. It&rsquo;s unlike anything ever attempted before in the UK and aims to bring conservation to life &ndash; taking visitors on an adventure where, for a few hours at least, they feel like they&rsquo;ve been transported to South East Asia.</p> <p>We&rsquo;re incredibly excited about the year ahead.</p> </blockquote> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="" src="/~/media/news/2015/How the inside of the Monsoon Forest part of Islands will look Custom.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <figcaption>How the inside of the Monsoon Forest, part of Islands, will look.</figcaption> </figure></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:02 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{41094E39-1E11-4BAD-8596-B53103B5DFCE}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/stock-take-2015</link><title>Who\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds in the zoo? Chester Zoo\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds new animals line-up to be counted ahead of move to biggest ever UK zoo exhibit</title><description><p>Keepers at Chester Zoo are used to tallying up penguins, meerkats and lemurs as part of their compulsory annual animal count. But with a huge new area set to open at the zoo in 2015, there\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds an array of other weird and wonderful species to keep track of during this year\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds census...</p><figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Dead leaf mantis" src="/~/media/news/2014/stocktake/A dead leaf mantis - one of 30 currently at the zoo (2).ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <figcaption>SUMMARY: Keepers at Chester Zoo have embarked on their annual head count of every animal at the zoo, which houses over 400 different species. Thousands of animals, many of them endangered, are part of the compulsory count which is required by law as part of the zoo&rsquo;s licence. The vital details of each and every individual are noted down so that the zoo can help worldwide breeding programmes. And as Chester prepares to open the biggest development in UK zoo history in spring, it has been a particularly busy year and a host of new exotic species need to be added to the records. (Photo: Herpetology keeper Heather Prince with a dead leaf mantis). </figcaption> </figure> <p>Keepers at Chester Zoo will welcome in the New Year armed with clipboards and pens as they make a note of every single animal in their care.</p> <p>The compulsory count is required as part of the zoo&rsquo;s licence and every creature, from the most handsome lion to the most bizarre-looking beetle, is duly totted up.</p> <p>Over 11,000 animals were recorded at the last census. But, as the zoo prepares to unveil a &pound;30m expansion in 2015, staff have their work cut out this time around with a whole host of exotic new arrivals to add to the records.</p> <div class="video">   <iframe frameborder="0" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/Aw-_DNBT9bk?rel=0"> </iframe> <div class="video-mask video-mask__top"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__right"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__bottom"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__left"></div> </div> <p>The new development, called <em>Islands</em>, is the biggest in UK zoo history and will recreate habitats from the Phillipines, Bali, Sulawesi, Papua, Sumba and Sumatra. Thousands of animals &ndash; including bizarre species like dead leaf mantids, Javan humphead lizards and tentacled snakes - have already arrived at the zoo ahead of its opening next spring.</p> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Aquarium team manager Andrea Swatman with one of Chester Zoo's tentacled snakes " src="/~/media/news/2014/stocktake/Aquarium team manager Andrea Swatman with one of Chester Zoos tentacled snakes 2.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <figcaption>Aquarium team manager Andrea Swatman with one of Chester Zoo's tentacled snakes</figcaption> </figure> <p>Herpetology keeper Heather Prince said:</p> <blockquote> <p>Tallying up our new super-sized Asian forest turtles doesn't provide us with too much of a headache but trying to count the hundreds of stick insects or dozens of mantids is a bit more of challenge!</p> </blockquote> <p>The zoo&rsquo;s records coordinator Liz Ball, responsible for compiling the data, added:</p> <blockquote> <p>Records at the zoo are regularly updated to allow for any births, deaths, departures and arrivals - with every animal having a 'passport' detailing exactly who it is, where it was born and who its ancestors are - ensuring the best possible management of vital worldwide conservation-breeding programmes.</p> <p>But it's all hands on deck as keepers help double check the data with a full head-count - a process which zoos must go through by law in order to comply with the Zoo Licensing Act 1981.</p> <p>With so many new animals coming in to take up residence in our new Islands development, we&rsquo;ve got an even bigger challenge than usual. Dozens of new species have arrived well in advance of its opening in spring 2015 and they&rsquo;re already breeding well. It means there are a heck of a lot of new heads to count &ndash; with the hundreds of weird and wonderful bugs being the trickiest!</p> <p>It&rsquo;s an incredibly exciting time for the zoo though and, even though there&rsquo;s a lot of extra work, it&rsquo;s really nice to be able to add all of the wonderful new arrivals to the count.</p> </blockquote> <h2>Notes to editors</h2> <ul> pictures 2014 </title><description><p>Glowing amphibians, new arrivals, pioneering operations, a television drama and some vital conservation work. Chester Zoo\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds media team select the images that defined 2014...</p><h2>January</h2> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Glow in dark frogs - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/year-in-pics/Frogs-45.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <p>Golden mantella frogs were<a href="/attractions-and-exhibits/zoo-news/silicone-implants-for-frogs"> implanted with a fluorescent silicone gel</a>, which allows keepers to easily identify individuals in their group of 80 frogs.</p> <p>It was the first time the technique had ever been attempted on the tiny Madagascan frog, which weighs less than just one gramme. &nbsp;</p> <p>The unique and innovative tags were monitored by amphibian experts who deemed them a great success.&nbsp;</p> <p>The zoo&rsquo;s curator of lower vertebrates and invertebrates, Dr Gerardo Garcia, has since travelled to Madagascar to train local conservationists in how to deploy the method to track the progress of the critically endangered species in the wild. </p> <h2>February</h2> <figure /> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Zebra - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/year-in-pics/Zebra-27.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <p>Grevy&rsquo;s zebra foal Merida became the first of her kind to be born at the zoo in 34 years <a href="/attractions-and-exhibits/zoo-news/grevys-zebra-born">when she arrived in February</a> to first-time parents Nadine and Mac.</p> <p>The Grevy&rsquo;s zebra is an endangered species found in small and isolated populations in Ethiopia and Northern Kenya where it&rsquo;s thought that fewer than 2,500 are left.&nbsp; </p> <h2>March</h2> <div class="video"><iframe src="//www.youtube.com/embed/XLeOkKsd8is?rel=0" frameborder="0"></iframe> <div class="video-mask video-mask__top"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__right"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__bottom"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__left"></div> </div> <p>The zoo released the first video animation of how its <a href="/islands">new &pound;30m Islands project</a> will look.</p> <p>The computer-generated footage of the &ldquo;biggest and most ambitious development in UK zoo history&rdquo; was issued to mark the start of English Tourism Week.</p> <p>Islands will see visitors set off an expedition - moving through detailed recreations of habitats in the Philippines, Bali, Sulawesi, Papua, Sumba and Sumatra. They will walk over bridges, travel in boats and see buildings that are architecturally identical to those found in South East Asia.</p> <p>It will open in spring 2015. See more <a href="/islands">on our special Islands website here</a>.</p> <h2>April</h2> <figure /> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Orangutans - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/year-in-pics/OrangUtan-40.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <p>Vets, keepers and doctors swung into action as 49kg <a href="/attractions-and-exhibits/zoo-news/orangutan-sinus-operation">orangutan Vicky successfully underwent a sinus operation</a> &ndash; the first time the procedure had ever been carried out in the UK.</p> <p>Vicky, a Bornean orangutan, was actually from Blackpool Zoo but, along with three other orangutans, was staying at Chester whilst a new exhibit in Blackpool was being built.</p> <p>Chester Zoo vet Steve Unwin said:</p> <blockquote> <p>It&rsquo;s fantastic that we&rsquo;ve been able to do this for Vicky. &nbsp;Her chronic sinusitis may have made her feel &lsquo;thick headed&rsquo; and made her more susceptible to picking up infections. This operation will dramatically improve things for her, make her much more comfortable.</p> </blockquote> <h2>May</h2> <figure /> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Tripa - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/year-in-pics/Tripa the baby Sumatran orangutan at Chester Zoo.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <p>Primate experts at the zoo<a href="/global/press-and-media/press-releases/dental-health-study-helps-wild-orangutans"> began a study on their orangutans' teeth</a> in a bid to help conservation projects thousands of miles away in Malaysia and Indonesia, where the animals often need to be moved if they come into conflict with humans, or their habitat is threatened by deforestation.</p> <p>To decide if they can move the animals safely, conservationists need to know if they're old enough to live independently. Young orangutans are dependent on their mother for eight to nine years - longer than any other animal apart from humans. However it&rsquo;s very difficult to tell the age of an orangutan.&nbsp;</p> <p>That&rsquo;s why keepers at the zoo started gathering new information on the emergence of teeth in their young orangutans &ndash; to help improve age estimations of orangutans observed in the wild and orphaned orangutans in rehabilitation facilities in South East Asia, whose dates of birth are usually unknown.&nbsp; </p> <h2>June</h2> <figure /> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Bernie spectacled bear - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/year-in-pics/Bernie-24.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <p>Four-year-old <a href="/attractions-and-exhibits/zoo-news/spectacled-bear-bernardo">spectacled bear Bernardo arrived</a> from the USA as part of the zoo&rsquo;s plans to breed the animals.</p> <p>It&rsquo;s rare that any zoo animals travel between Europe and the USA but Bernardo&rsquo;s move brought important new blood to the European population of spectacled bears &ndash; a species classed by the International Union of Conservation of Nature (IUCN) as being vulnerable to extinction in the wild. </p> <h2>July</h2> <figure /> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Python - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/year-in-pics/Python-17.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <p>Staff carried out an <a href="/attractions-and-exhibits/zoo-news/giant-python-given-ultrasound">annual health check on a 23ft-long python</a> &ndash; including using ultrasound to scan its heart.</p> <p>Reticulated pythons are the longest species of snake in the world so it took a team of 12 people to examine it.</p> <p>The huge reptile - named JF - is thought to be one of the largest of her kind in Europe weighing in at around 60kgs. </p> <h2>August</h2> <figure /> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Mouse deer - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/year-in-pics/MouseDeer-6.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <p>A male Philippine mouse deer described as &ldquo;not much bigger than a rabbit&rdquo; <a href="/attractions-and-exhibits/zoo-news/new-arrival-mouse-deer">moved to the zoo in August</a>.&nbsp;</p> <p>The little deer &ndash; one of the smallest hoofed animals in the world - is one of just 15 to be found in zoos in Europe and is currently the only one of his kind in the UK.</p> <p>But the zoo hopes to eventually find a female as part of its plans to join the endangered species breeding programme for the threatened animals. </p> <h2>September</h2> <figure /> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Our Zoo  - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/year-in-pics/038_Oakfield_17March14_DH6A4865 final.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <p><em>Our Zoo</em>, <a href="/global/about-us/our-zoo-bbc-drama">a six-part TV drama based on the inspiring story of the zoo&rsquo;s founder George Mottershead</a> and his family in the 1930s, opened on BBC One.&nbsp;</p> <p>The drama followed George&rsquo;s incredible journey as he drove himself and his family to realise his ambition to transform a ramshackle house on the outskirts of Chester into a unique visitor attraction that would change forever the way zoos keep animals. </p> <h2>October</h2> <figure /> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Saki monkey - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/year-in-pics/SakiMonkey-13.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <p>A six-week-old <a href="/attractions-and-exhibits/zoo-news/white-face-saki-monkeys">white-faced saki monkey made its debut</a>, hitching a ride with mum Tabiti.</p> <p>Keepers described Tabiti as a &lsquo;great mum&rsquo; and dad Kwinti as a &lsquo;protective dad.&rsquo;</p> <p>White-faced saki monkeys are found in tropical rainforests in parts of South America. </p> <h2>November</h2> <figure /> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Dormouse - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/year-in-pics/dtmouse4.ashx" />&nbsp;</div> <p>A female hazel dormouse is held by a member of the zoo&rsquo;s conservation team.&nbsp; </p> <p>The zoo is working with Natural Resources Wales (NRW) and the Wildlife Trusts to collect scientific data on the dormice &ndash; a rare species which is protected in the UK and Europe.</p> <p>The project, in which each individual dormouse is microchipped, is providing important information on dormouse habitat use, life expectancy, population size and breeding behaviour which is helping to guide more effective dormouse conservation in the UK.</p> <p>The project has been running for 10 years making it the biggest study of its type to be carried out on a small mammal species in the UK. </p> <h2>December</h2> <figure /> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="" src="/~/media/news/2014/year-in-pics/Giraffe-11.ashx?h=1152&amp;w=800" /><br /> </div> <p>Christmas came early for keepers with the very special delivery of a rare Rothschild giraffe calf. </p> <p>The 6ft (1.8m) youngster - a female named <em>Zahra </em>- was born in the early hours of December 22 to mum <em>Aiofe</em> and dad <em>Meru.</em></p> <p>Curator of mammals at Chester Zoo, Tim Rowlands, said:</p> <blockquote> <p>Giraffes give birth standing up and the calves fall about 6ft - so they really do come down to Earth with a bump. But we&rsquo;re happy to report that our new, not so little, youngster is doing well and is already confident on her long legs.</p> <p>Everyone at the zoo is thrilled with our newcomer and she has really added to our Christmas and New Year celebrations.</p> </blockquote></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:02 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{F72A032A-3124-4C54-8D16-6DE3DF12DC64}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/rare-baby-giraffe-zahra-born</link><title>Walking tall! Rare baby giraffe, Zahra, born at Chester Zoo</title><description><p>A rare Rothschild\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds giraffe has made her debut at Chester Zoo.</p><figure> <div style="text-align: center;" class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="" src="/~/media/news/2014/Giraffe-10.ashx?h=800&amp;w=1202" /><em>Lofty debut: Visitors to Chester Zoo are getting their first glimpse of a rare baby giraffe born just before Christmas. Keepers have named the female Rothschild&rsquo;s giraffe calf &ndash; one of the world&rsquo;s most endangered subspecies &ndash; Zahra, which means &lsquo;flower&rsquo; in Swahili. </em><br /> </div> </figure> <p> </p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <p>Rothschild&rsquo;s are one of the world&rsquo;s most endangered subspecies, with recent estimates suggesting less than 1,100 are left in the wild. <br /> <br /> The 6ft (1.8m) calf was born in the lead up to Christmas to mum <em>Aiofe</em> and dad <em>Meru</em>. Keepers have named their lanky new arrival <em>Zahra</em>, meaning &lsquo;flower&rsquo; in Swahili. <br /> <br /> Curator of mammals at Chester Zoo, Tim Rowlands, said:<strong><br /> <br /> </strong></p> <blockquote><strong>&ldquo;Giraffes give birth standing up and the calves fall about 6ft - so they really do come down to Earth with a bump. But we&rsquo;re happy to report that our new, not-so-little, youngster is doing well and is already confident on her long legs.<br /> <br /> &ldquo;Everyone at the zoo is thrilled with <em>Zahra</em> and she has really added to our Christmas and New Year celebrations.&rdquo; </strong></blockquote> <p><strong><img alt="" src="/~/media/news/2014/Giraffe-8.ashx?h=1202&amp;w=800" /><br /> </strong>The zoo now has a herd of eight Rothschild giraffes. <strong>&nbsp;<br /> <br /> </strong>Mr Rowlands added: <strong><br /> <br /> </strong></p> <blockquote><strong>&ldquo;Whilst it&rsquo;s great that we have a nice herd here, in the wild this species really is under threat. Numbers are declining at a worrying rate due to a massive upsurge in poaching for their meat.<br /> <br /> &ldquo;So when people come here and see the likes of <em>Zahra</em> and see what magnificent animals Rothschild&rsquo;s giraffes are, we really want them to stop and think about the plight of the species in the wild. Rothschild&rsquo;s giraffes are of high conservation priority and the need for a concerted conservation effort has never been more urgent.&rdquo;</strong><br /> </blockquote><strong></strong> <p><strong> </strong></p> <p>On top of its successful breeding record, Chester Zoo has supported important projects in the wild, including the first ever scientific review of the Rothschild&rsquo;s giraffe. Its aim is to develop a long-term conservation strategy for the species in Africa. </p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <h2>Rothschild giraffe facts</h2> <ul>     <li>Mum Aiofe was born on 1 March 1998. She is 16 years old</li>     <li>Dad is called Meru</li>     <li>The baby &ndash; a female named Zahra - was born at around 3am on Dec 22. She is Aiofe&rsquo;s second calf. </li>     <li>Zahra means &lsquo;flower&rsquo; in Swahili</li>     <li>Rothschild&rsquo;s giraffe are named after zoologist Lord Walter Rothschild, founder of the National History Museum in Tring, Hertfordshire</li>     <li>They are also known as the baringo or Ugandan giraffe</li>     <li>The species is identified by its broader dividing white lines and has no spots beneath the knees</li>     <li>Giraffe population figures are declining across Africa</li>     <li>Rothschild&rsquo;s &nbsp;giraffes are classed as endangered by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) with current population estimates suggesting less than 1,100 remain in the wild</li>     <li>With less than 1,100 individuals remaining in the wild the Rothschild's giraffe is more endangered than species such as African elephants and giant pandas</li>     <li>Roughly one-third of the surviving population of Rothschild&rsquo;s giraffes live in zoos where carefully co-ordinated breeding programmes are creating a safety-net population for the species</li>     <li>Once wide-ranging across Kenya, Uganda and Sudan, the Rothschild&rsquo;s giraffe has been almost totally eliminated from much of its former range and now only survives in a few small, isolated populations in Kenya and Uganda</li>     <li>The main threat to the species now is loss of habitat and poaching for meat and hides</li>     <li>In the past, giraffes were hunted for their tails, which were used as good-luck charms, sewing thread and even fly swats</li>     <li>The species is one of the most endangered of the nine sub-species of giraffe</li>     <li>Chester Zoo now has eight Rothschild giraffes &ndash; <em>Meru, Aoife, Dagma, Orla, Tula, Kanzi, Millie</em> and <em>Zahra</em></li> </ul></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:02 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{F9165D53-4BEB-4256-8B7D-79764471F4E1}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/top-10-zoo-babies-2014</link><title>Chester Zoo\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds top 10 babies of 2014</title><description><p>Chester Zoo has seen a host of important animal births in 2014 \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd including several \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdzoo firsts\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd.</p><p>The zoo says careful planning, excellent husbandry, expert keeping staff, top facilities, a detailed animal nutrition programme and scientific underpinning are factors that have all come together to achieve their breeding bonanza.</p> <p>Here&rsquo;s the zoo&rsquo;s list of the top 10 baby animal success stories of the year&hellip;  </p> <h2>1. Merida the Grevy&rsquo;s zebra foal</h2> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Zebra - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/zoo-babies/Zebra-3.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p>A rare Grevy&rsquo;s zebra foal, a female named Merida, was born in February &ndash; the first of its kind to be born at the zoo for over 30 years.</p> <p>Curator of mammals, Tim Rowlands, said:</p> <blockquote> <p>Since our female zebras arrived a few years ago we have worked very hard to breed this highly endangered species and the arrival of this foal is not only a really good achievement for us but also good news for the species as a whole.</p> </blockquote> <p>The zoo is part of a European breeding programme for the species which is the largest of all zebras and distinctive from its cousins given that it has the narrowest stripes.</p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <h2>2. Jake the Viysayan warty pig</h2> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Warty pig - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/zoo-babies/WartyPig-12.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p> An extremely rare piglet was born in May. </p> <p> Given that the species boasts spiky, almost mohawk-like hair style on their heads, mum Viv and dad Sid were named after punk rockers Vivienne Westwood and Sid Vicious. </p> <p> And their new charge was given a title to follow suit &ndash; Jake, after Jake Burns from the band Stiff Little Fingers.  </p> <p> Only 200 Visayan warty pigs are thought to be left in their native habitat in the Philippines &ndash; making them the rarest of all wild pigs. </p> <p> Keeper Lucy Edwards said: </p> <blockquote> <p> Visayan warty pigs are critically endangered and face an extremely high risk of becoming extinct in the wild. </p> <p> They&rsquo;ve suffered a drastic population crash in recent times with widespread commercial logging, illegal logging and agricultural expansion devastating vast amounts of their natural habitat. They&rsquo;re also being over-hunted and their meat can often command at least double the price of domestic pork in local markets and some restaurants. </p> <p> It really is a battle against time to save them.  </p> </blockquote> <p> Chester Zoo was the first in the UK to welcome Visayan warty pigs, a species that gets its name from three pairs of fleshy warts on the boar's face. The warts protect them from rival pigs' tusks during a fight. </p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <h2> 3. World Cup penguin chicks </h2> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Penguins - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/zoo-babies/Penguins-12.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p> When four Humboldt penguin chicks hatched in April a real poser for keepers was what to call them. </p> <p> Lead penguin keeper Karen Neech said: </p> <blockquote> <p> Choosing names for the chicks is always tricky but with one eye on this summer&rsquo;s World Cup in Brazil, we decided to kick off this year&rsquo;s football campaign with some stars of our own. </p> <p>Footballers have very strict diets and things are just the same for our new arrivals. But whereas footballers can look forward to a protein shake ours grow strong on a diet of regurgitated &lsquo;fish smoothie&rsquo; provided by their parents. </p> </blockquote> <p> Step forward Rooney (named after England forward Wayne), Gerrard (after current England captain Steven), Banks (after 1966 World Cup winning goalkeeper Gordon) and Moore (after 1966 World Cup winning captain Bobby). </p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <h2> 4. The zoo&rsquo;s first warthogs </h2> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Warthog - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/zoo-babies/Warthogs-9 (2).ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p> In May, two warthogs also became the first of their kind to be born at the zoo. </p> <p> The piglets, who at the time stood at just 30cm tall, arrived to first time parents Tamzin and Magnum.  </p> <p> Curator of mammals, Tim Rowlands, said:</p> <blockquote> <p>This is the zoo&rsquo;s first ever warthog family and so of course we&rsquo;re absolutely thrilled. </p> <p>Our tiny piglets are almost hairless, wrinkly and grey and already have their trademark protruding warts from which they get their name. Some may not consider them to be as &lsquo;cute&rsquo; as many of the other babies we&rsquo;ve had born here of late, but to us, they&rsquo;re just as special. </p> <p>&nbsp;</p> </blockquote> <h2>5. Unusual new arrival is a real pretty Polly </h2> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Macaw - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/zoo-babies/Macaw-1.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p>Keepers at the zoo provided around-the-clock care to a rare hyacinth macaw chick, named Jesse.</p> <p>The baby bird was fed up to nine times a day in a Tupperware tub which acted as a crib.</p> <p>The species is endangered in the wild where populations have undergone rapid reductions in recent years due to the illegal pet trade and habitat loss.</p> <p>Keeper Karen Neech said:</p> <blockquote> <p>It&rsquo;s hard to believe that our chick will eventually start to spring some beautiful deep blue feathers &ndash; at the moment it looks more like a dinosaur crossed with a plucked chicken!</p> </blockquote> <p>Hyacinth macaws are the world&rsquo;s largest parrot and are found in Brazil, Bolivia and Paraguay.</p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <h2>6. Little humbug Zathras  </h2> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Tapir at Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/zoo-babies/Tapir-33.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p>Zookeepers announced the birth of a baby tapir in August.</p> <p>The tiny calf - the first male to be born at the zoo for eight years - was given the name Zathras. </p> <p>Curator of mammals, Tim Rowlands, said:</p> <blockquote> <p>At the moment Zathras looks a bit like a little humbug. His brown coat currently features lots of white stripes and spots which will eventually disappear as he gets to around six-to-nine months old. The markings act as camouflage in the wild &ndash; mimicking speckled sunlight on the forest floor. He won&rsquo;t be little for long though as new youngsters tend to double their weight in the first 14-21 days alone. </p> </blockquote> <p>The zoo is a keen supporter of a conservation initiative which has been finding out valuable information about behaviour patterns and movements of tapirs in several key areas of Brazil.</p> <p>It is hoped this research will help safeguard the future of the fascinating species which is increasingly hunted for its meat and for its hide, which is used to make sandals.</p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <h2>7. Baby meerkats</h2> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Meerkat - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/zoo-babies/Meerkats-14.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p> A number of baby meerkats arrived mob-handed with litters born in April and August. </p> <p> Team manager Dave White said:</p> <blockquote> <p>All of the pups are full of rough and tumble. They&rsquo;re a real handful for mum, dad and the other adults in the mob who, between them, are doing their best to keep them in check. </p> <p>&nbsp;</p> </blockquote> <h2> 8. Lasola the anoa calf </h2> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Anoa at Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/zoo-babies/Anoa-21.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p> A &lsquo;devilish&rsquo; new arrival was born at the zoo on October 22.  </p> <p> The rare anoa calf &ndash; the world&rsquo;s smallest species of wild cattle &ndash; arrived after a 282 day pregnancy for first time mum, Oana. </p> <p> Keepers named the new female youngster, Lasola.   </p> <p> Anoa live in forests and swamps on the Indonesian island of Sulawesi but are listed as endangered by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), with just 2,500 mature individuals estimated to remain. </p> <p> Assistant curator of mammals, Dr Nick Davis, said: </p> <blockquote> <p> In the wild they&rsquo;ve been given the unfair tag as being &lsquo;demons&rsquo; of the forest. As a result they&rsquo;re persecuted by farmers who hold them responsible for damage to their cattle. </p> <p> Take one look at our new calf and it&rsquo;s impossible to see how anyone could label or harm them in such a way &ndash; they&rsquo;re a very shy and secretive animal.   </p> <p>&nbsp;</p> </blockquote> <h2> 9. Sand lizards bred at the zoo return to sand dunes  </h2> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Sand lizards - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/zoo-babies/Sand lizards reintroduced by Chester Zoo (4).ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p> Rare lizards, which were believed to have gone extinct in Wales around 60 years ago, were released on sand dunes in the north of the country in a bid to boost struggling populations.  </p> <p> The sand lizards - an endangered UK species - were bred at a number of specialist breeding centres, including the zoo, during the summer. </p> <p> The captive breeding and reintroduction programme is helping the lizards to make a comeback in Talacre, North Wales. </p> <p> Herpetology keeper Ruth Smith said: </p> <blockquote> <p> Sand lizards are the UK&rsquo;s rarest lizard and populations in some areas are so low that we can&rsquo;t just rely on protecting the site, we have to help breed them to boost their numbers. </p> <p> This year we&rsquo;ve reintroduced 31 juvenile lizards to the wild - a record for the zoo so we&rsquo;re really pleased.   </p> <p> Slowly and surely we&rsquo;re getting them back into areas where historically they used to live. </p> <p>&nbsp;</p> </blockquote> <h2> 10. Gentle lemur birth is a first for zoo </h2> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="GentleLemur - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/zoo-babies/GentleLemur-12.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p>A wide-eyed lemur marked yet another first for the zoo when it arrived in June. </p> <p>The new youngster &ndash; an Alaotran gentle lemur - arrived to mum Molly and dad Fady.</p> <p>Curator of mammals, Tim Rowlands, said:</p> <blockquote> <p>This is a critically endangered species that is faced with a very real threat of extinction in the wild. This is the first time the species has ever bred at Chester Zoo and so we&rsquo;re thrilled.</p> </blockquote> <p> And who could forget&hellip;</p> <h2><a href="http://www.chesterzoo.org/attractions-and-exhibits/zoo-news/critically-endangered-ducklings-hatch-at-chester-zoo?page=4">Baer's pochard ducklings</a></h2> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Ducklings - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/zoo-babies/Ducklings-11.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <figure> <h2><a href="/global/press-and-media/press-releases/smallest-baby-deer-born">Pudu fawn</a></h2> <p class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Pudu - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/zoo-babies/Pudu-3 (2).ashx" /> </p> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </figure> <figure> <h2><a href="/global/press-and-media/press-releases/rock-hyrax-born">Rock hyrax</a></h2> <img alt="Rock hyrax - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/zoo-babies/RockHyrax-4.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </figure> <figure> <h2><a href="/global/press-and-media/press-releases/rare-monkey-born">Buffy-headed capuchin</a></h2> <img alt="Capuchins - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/zoo-babies/Capuchins-17.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </figure> <figure> <h2><a href="/global/press-and-media/press-releases/dwarf-mongoose-pups-emerge">Dwarf mongoose</a></h2> <img alt="Mongoose - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/zoo-babies/Mongoose-6.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </figure> <figure> <h2><a href="/attractions-and-exhibits/zoo-news/rare-northern-bald-ibis-checks">Northern bald ibis</a></h2> <img alt="Ibis - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/zoo-babies/Ibis-3.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </figure> <figure> <h2><a href="/global/press-and-media/press-releases/rare-african-crane-chicks">West-African black-crowned crane chicks</a></h2> <img alt="Cranes - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/zoo-babies/Cranes-29.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </figure></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:02 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{1798C7CF-0D4A-4242-924F-1DC05F500D24}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/chester-zoo-maasai-olympics</link><title>Chester Zoo sponsors the hunt for medals, not lions, at the Maasai Olympics</title><description><p>Chester Zoo is to be the main sponsor of the 2014 Maasai Olympics \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd an event which is using sport to replace wildlife hunting as traditional warrior activity in East Africa.</p><figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Maasai olympics" src="/~/media/news/2014/Warriors compete in the Maasai Olympics.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p>The games, which will be held on December 13 at the Kimana Wildlife Sanctury at the base of Mt. Kilimanjaro in Kenya, are bringing a fresh approach to animal conservation.</p> <p>Killing animals to compete for recognition, display &lsquo;manliness&rsquo;, impress women and identify leaders has long been embedded in Maasai culture. However, conservationists fear it has reached a tipping point and has pushed certain species towards the brink of extinction.</p> <p>Conservation experts, alongside spiritual leaders, village elders and leading Maasai figures have therefore worked together to develop the Maasai Olympics. Its aim is to stop the killing of animals and protect wildlife by showing Maasai warriors that there are other ways to display bravery.</p> <p>The individual athletic events &ndash; based on traditional warrior skills &ndash; will include the 200m sprint, 800m sprint, spear throwing, high jump and a 5k run.&nbsp;</p> <p>And, for the very first time, women will also compete in two events &ndash; the 100 and 1500 meters.</p> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Warriors at Maasai olympics" src="/~/media/news/2014/Warriors compete at the Maasai Olympics.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p>Chester Zoo&rsquo;s education programmes manager, Dr Maggie Esson, will be travelling to the event to present the Chester Zoo Conservation Prize in recognition of the Maasai village (known as a manyatta) that has done the most for wildlife conservation.&nbsp;</p> <p>Dr Esson said:</p> <blockquote> <p>The Maasai Olympics has conservation at its heart. But it is a sports competition just like any other with winners and losers, close finishes and memorable victories.</p> <p>The road to protecting species is never a straight one but we&rsquo;re delighted to be a part of such a ground-breaking event.</p> </blockquote> <p>Medals, trophies and prizes, including cash and a premier breeding bull for the winning manyatta, will be given to the winners.</p> <p>Kenyan Olympic gold medalist and world 800-metre record holder David Rudisha, a former Maasai warrior, will be the patron of the games.</p></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:02 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{B668A753-487D-4BD8-B551-468FE8A6ADB9}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/new-dormouse-discoveries</link><title>New discoveries from a decade of dormouse diaries</title><description><p>A unique decade-long study has unearthed fascinating new traits in a tiny mammal species. </p><figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Dormouse - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/dtmouse4.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <figcaption>A female hazel dormouse is held by a member of the conservation team from Chester Zoo. The zoo is working with Natural Resources Wales (NRW) and the Wildlife Trusts to collect scientific data on the dormice \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd a rare species which is protected in the UK and Europe. The project, in which each individual dormouse is microchipped, is providing important information on dormouse habitat use, life expectancy, population size and breeding behaviour which is helping to guide more effective dormouse conservation in the UK. The project has been running for 10 years making it the biggest study of this type to be carried out on a small mammal species in the UK.  </figcaption> </figure> <p>The ground-breaking research has shed new light on the mysterious hazel dormouse, including the fact that females have a promiscuous side. </p> <p>Conservationists took hair samples from the dormice and used DNA techniques to prove that females can have offspring sired by multiple fathers in the same litter. </p> <p>The study - which is the largest and longest-running of its kind in the UK - is being carried out by conservationists from Chester Zoo, alongside staff from Natural Resources Wales (NRW), the local Wildlife Trusts, Denbighshire County Council and volunteers.</p> <p>It also found that female dormice can sometimes breed twice in the same year, and that very occasionally they breed before they are a year old. Both these behaviours have been observed in dormice in Europe, but rarely in the UK. In fact, breeding in &lsquo;young of the year&rsquo; had never been recorded in the UK before.</p> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Chester zoo staff in the field" src="/~/media/news/2014/dtmouse8.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p>Chester Zoo&rsquo;s biodiversity officer Sarah Bird said:</p> <blockquote> <p>Our study has shed new light on the ecology of our dormice and highlighted factors which are important for their survival in the UK. Promiscuity in females had never been recorded before; and it will increase genetic diversity within litters, helping population survival. Equally important are the other breeding behaviours we have seen. It is likely that those years when females breed twice, and the young of the year also breed, is when populations can really increase. These behaviours are likely to be critical for healthy sustainable dormouse populations in the UK. </p> </blockquote> <p>The scientific data collected is also providing important information on dormouse habitat use, life expectancy, and population changes, and helping to deliver more effective dormouse conservation.</p> <p>Hazel dormice are protected under European law and the UK is required to monitor the species. </p> <p>Since recording began in the UK in the early 1990s, a decline in both the number of dormice, and the range of the species, has been observed. Experts believe the decline to have been taking place for at least 100 years due to loss and fragmentation of their habitat.</p> <p>In 2005, 45,000 hazel dormice were estimated to live in the UK. Today the national downward population trend continues though some evidence indicates the rate of decline may be slowing at last. </p> <p>However, at a site in Bontuchel in North Wales, the survey has revealed a large stable population of dormice. </p> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Dormouse field research" src="/~/media/news/2014/dtmouse11.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p>Sarah added:</p> <blockquote> <p>The hazel dormouse is a protected species in Europe and they&rsquo;re super, charismatic little animals. </p> <p>Our survey site in North Wales is on the very north western edge of their European range and, from the very start, we&rsquo;ve been surprised by how many hazel dormice are there.</p> <p>That&rsquo;s why it&rsquo;s a very important project and a very important site for study &ndash; to understand why this woodland is so good for dormice.</p> <p>Our vets and conservation team and project partners have been able to visit the site four times each year for the last 10 years. Using our veterinary expertise, we&rsquo;ve marked 920 dormice with tiny microchips in that time. This has enabled us to build up a huge amount of really important and unique data. We now know a huge amount about these dormice now &ndash; including how long they live, how their weight fluctuates throughout the year and how many survive winter hibernation.</p> <p>It is clear that habitat management by Natural Resources Wales (NRW) is making a big difference. Leaving woodland unmanaged is not good for dormice.</p> </blockquote> <p>Mike Whitley, local area manager for Natural Resources Wales, said:</p> <blockquote> <p>We have one of the healthiest populations of dormice in the UK here at Bontuchel.</p> <p>The coppice management works we carry out each year creates the just the right habitat conditions for the dormice to flourish while also making this woodland a really great place for people to visit.</p> </blockquote> <h2>Dormice facts</h2> <ul>     <li>The hazel dormouse is a European protected species</li>     <li>The hazel or common dormouse (Muscardinus avellanarius) is the only dormouse species that is native to the UK</li>     <li>The UK is required to monitor them and to take steps to achieve and maintain a &lsquo;favourable conservation status&rsquo;</li>     <li>The National Dormouse Monitoring Programme was set up to monitor the population and find out what&rsquo;s happening to numbers</li>     <li>Since recording began in the UK in the early 1990s a long-term decline in both the number of dormice, and the range of the species, has been observed. The decline is believed to have been going on for at least 100 years, although recent results indicate that the decline could now be slowing</li>     <li>In 2005 the UK hazel dormouse population was estimated to be around 45,000 animals</li>     <li>An ongoing dormouse reintroduction programme is helping to slowly extend the current range</li>     <li>Chester Zoo has helped to monitor a site in Bontuchel in North Wales for 10 years.
