The survey has shown that the dormouse population is stable &ndash; the dormice at the site are not following the national downward population trend. This makes it an extremely important site for study - to try to understand why this woodland is so good for dormice</li>     <li>Over 900 hazel dormice have been microchipped at Bontuchel over 10 years</li>     <li>230 artificial nest boxes have been created to help the population thrive</li>     <li>The project has so far provided data for one PhD, three MSc and numerous BSC projects, another PhD is in progress. The project has contributed to papers at three international dormouse conferences over the last nine years and produced several peer review journal papers</li>     <li>The hazel part of their name comes from the hazel nuts they feed on, and the dormouse from the French word &lsquo;dormir,&rsquo; which means &lsquo;to sleep&rsquo; &ndash; very apt as they sleep for two thirds of their lives</li> </ul></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:02 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{184752FA-C3C8-4CC4-97A5-06C67CD72629}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/rare-monkey-born</link><title>Rare monkey born at Chester Zoo</title><description><p>A rare capuchin monkey born at Chester Zoo has given a boost to a species seriously threatened with extinction in the wild. </p><figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Buffy-headed capuchins - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/monkeys-and-apes/monkeys/Capuchins-2.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <figcaption>HOLD ON! A 12-week-old buffy-headed capuchin monkey hitches a ride with mum at Chester Zoo. The buffy-headed capuchin is one of the world&rsquo;s rarest species of primates.</figcaption> </figure> <p>The buffy-headed capuchin, which is listed by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) as being critically endangered in the wild, arrived after a 180 day pregnancy for its 15-year-old mum.</p> <p> The arrival brings the number of buffy-headed capuchins at the zoo to eight. </p> <p>Assistant curator of mammals, Dr Nick Davis, said: </p> <blockquote> <p>The buffy-headed capuchin is one of the world&rsquo;s rarest species of primates. In the past they were abundant in the Atlantic rainforests of eastern Brazil but sadly they&rsquo;re now on the verge of disappearing from the wild because of severe destruction to their habitat and intense hunting. </p> <p>We&rsquo;re pleased to say though that our new youngster is doing extremely well and is now confidently out and about, being carried by mum.</p> </blockquote> <p> Keepers at the zoo won&rsquo;t know the sex of their new charge for several weeks.&nbsp; </p> <h2>Buffy-headed capuchin facts</h2> <ul>     <li> The buffy-headed capuchin is a fairly small monkey with reddish-brown fur and a sharply marked yellow to golden chest </li>     <li> They are also known as yellow-breasted or golden-bellied capuchins </li>     <li> Its Latin name is Cebus xanthosternos </li>     <li> Buffy-headed capuchins are endemic to small areas of rainforest on the Atlantic coast of Brazil </li>     <li> The species is classed as critically endangered in the wild by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN). This is a result of a severe population decline due to extensive habitat loss over the last 50 years. It is estimated that more than 80% of their natural range has been lost and the species is now only know to live in several small protected areas. They are also heavily hunted for meat and collected as pets </li>     <li> They have been named as one of the world&rsquo;s 25 most endangered primates by the IUCN </li>     <li> Their diet consists of a wide variety of fruits, seeds, stems, flowers and leaves as well as insects, spiders frogs, young birds and even small mammals </li>     <li> It is a social monkey that lives in groups, usually with more males than females&nbsp; </li>     <li> Males are slightly larger and heavier than females </li>     <li> The group communicates through barks, growls, screams, chatters, trills, twitters, purrs, whistles and warbles </li>     <li> Chester Zoo&rsquo;s new youngster was born on 13/08/2014. It is now three months old </li>     <li> Mum was born on 17/12/1988&nbsp; </li>     <li> Dad was born on 01/02/1991 </li>     <li> Both parents arrived at the zoo in 1996 from the Rio Primate Centre as part of setting up a population in European zoos&nbsp; </li>     <li> Gestation lasts 180 days and females give birth to just one offspring at a time </li> </ul></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:02 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{E58F10D6-74F9-4FB4-8FF0-27DFA36B0263}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/tourism-awards-2014</link><title>Lantern Magic lights up Marketing Cheshire Awards</title><description><p>We\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdre delighted to have won the award for Event of the Year for our Lantern Magic Christmas event at the recent Marketing Cheshire Annual Awards 2014.</p><figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Lantern Magic - Event of the Year - Chester ZOo" src="/~/media/news/2014/Marketing_Cheshire_Awards_2014_Celynnen_Photography_074.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p>The judges said:&nbsp;</p> <blockquote> <p>This was an excellent event which was well researched and well-targeted. With a clear understanding of the market segment and established customer service procedures there were very few things this contender could be marked down on. For creating a highly efficient and effective marketing campaign the winner of the Tourism Experience or Event of the Year is Lantern Magic at Chester Zoo.</p> </blockquote> <p>We were also pleased to pick up a commendation for Large Visitor Attraction.</p> <p>Jamie Christon, Managing Director said:&nbsp;</p> <blockquote> <p>The Marketing Cheshire Annual Awards highlight the uniqueness of our event for families after dark. To see visitors starting a new family tradition of coming to the zoo at Christmas and enjoying the calm atmosphere is just magical. We fought off stiff competition and we&rsquo;re delighted to be recognised for our efforts.</p> </blockquote> <p><a href="/attractions-and-exhibits/christmas-lantern-magic">Tickets for Lantern Magic</a>, now in its third year, are selling fast, with nearly all of this year&rsquo;s dates sold out already. We&rsquo;d like to thank all the teams involved, to The Lantern Company for creating our life-size lanterns and to our elves for making our event magical and loved by all ages.</p></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:02 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{DEE49E23-0B6C-4CFD-B5EA-B842C9248A0F}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/fischers-turacos-hand-reared</link><title>Keeping mum! New arrivals get a helping hand</title><description><p>THESE little birds are proving to be a handful for staff at Chester Zoo.</p><figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Fischers Turaco" src="/~/media/news/2014/Chicks-19.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p>The tiny Fischer&rsquo;s turacos (<em>Tauraco fischeri</em>) are being hand-reared after they were rejected by their first-time mum.</p> <p>Now curator of birds Andrew Owen has stepped into the role of parent, providing round the clock care and feeding the chicks every few hours.</p> <p>The duo have also been heading home with Andrew who uses tweezers to carefully feed them small pieces of chopped fruit.</p> <p><strong>&ldquo;It&rsquo;s not unusual for a first-time mum to feel a little unsure as to what&rsquo;s she&rsquo;s to do with her new charges so I&rsquo;m more than happy to step up and play parent.</strong></p> <p><strong>&ldquo;Encouraging them to eat does require some patience and a little encouragement but once they&rsquo;ve got full tummies then they&rsquo;re usually happy to nod off to sleep. As youngsters go, other than meal times, they&rsquo;ve been pretty un-demanding and I&rsquo;m relieved to say they&rsquo;ve not been keeping me up at night.</strong></p> <p><strong>&ldquo;In no time at all though they&rsquo;ll be ready to fledge and off to join the rest of the birds in the zoo,&rdquo; said Andrew.</strong></p> <p>The turacos are native to Kenya, Somalia and Tanzania where forest clearing and trapping prove a threat to long-term survival of the species.</p> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Fischers turaco - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/Chicks-2.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <h2>Fischer&rsquo;s turaco</h2> <ul>     <li>Fischer&rsquo;s turacos are native to forest and woodlands in Kenya, north-east Tanzania and south Somalia</li>     <li>There are around 2,500 left in the wild</li>     <li>Males and females differ considerably.  Adult males have black feathers with a striking white face.</li>     <li>The birds feed on fruit, flower buds and insects</li>     <li>Turacos always lay two eggs which incubate for 22-23 days</li>     <li>Despite their black feathers, the chicks will eventually sport colourful plumage and have a black, red and white crest</li> </ul></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:02 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{A0B9109D-C44C-4E64-93FE-B96D9FFA23FF}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/lowland-anoa-born</link><title>Endangered lowland anoa born at Chester Zoo</title><description><p>A devilish new arrival has been born at Chester Zoo. </p><figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Anoa calf at Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/hoofed-animals/anoa/Anoa-21.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <figcaption>Devilish new arrival: A rare anoa calf explores its enclosure at Chester Zoo. Anoa, the world&rsquo;s smallest species of wild cattle, are found only on the island of Sulawesi in Indonesia.</figcaption> </figure> <p>The rare anoa calf &ndash; the world&rsquo;s smallest species of wild cattle &ndash; arrived after a 282 day pregnancy for first time mum, Oana.</p> <p>Keepers have named the new female youngster, Lasola. </p> <p>Anoa live in forests and swamps on the Indonesian island of Sulawesi but are listed as endangered by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), with just 2,500 mature individuals estimated to remain. </p> <div class="video">   <iframe frameborder="0" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/V_lECf7bwRw?rel=0"> </iframe> <div class="video-mask video-mask__top"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__right"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__bottom"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__left"></div> </div>  <p>Assistant curator of mammals, Dr Nick Davis, said:</p> <blockquote> <p>As with many Indonesian island species, the lowland anoa faces an uncertain future.</p> <p>Hunting for their meat is a really serious threat to them. The taste is described as hot and fiery and men believe that eating the meat of this powerful, horned animal will give them prowess.</p> <p>Hunters are even managing to breach areas of Sulawesi which were thought to give protection to the anoas.</p> <p>The only way this hunting pressure can be reduced is through the establishment of better protected areas and education.</p> </blockquote> <p>The species, which is a miniature water buffalo, is sometimes referred to as the &lsquo;demon&rsquo; of the forest as local farmers wrongly believe them to come out of the forest at night and use their horns to puncture cattle.</p> <p><img alt="Anoa - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/hoofed-animals/anoa/Anoa-19.ashx" /></p> <p>Dr Davis added:</p> <blockquote> <p>In the wild they&rsquo;ve been given the unfair tag as being &lsquo;demons&rsquo; of the forest. As a result they&rsquo;re persecuted by farmers who hold them responsible for damage to their cattle.</p> <p>Take one look at our new calf and it&rsquo;s impossible to see how anyone could label or harm them in such a way &ndash; they&rsquo;re a very shy and secretive animal.</p> </blockquote> <p>Next spring the zoo&rsquo;s anoa family will move to a brand new exhibit when Islands, a new &pound;30m development, opens.</p> <p>Islands, which will recreate habitats in the Phillipines, Bali, Sulawesi, Papua, Sumba and Sumatra, is billed as the biggest and most ambitious expansion project in UK zoo history. </p> <p>Dr Davis added:</p> <blockquote> <p>Indonesian islands are treasure trove of unique and fragile plants and animals and that&rsquo;s why they&rsquo;re a big focus for our conservation work.</p> <p>When it opens next year we hope our new Islands zone will really put the spotlight on species such Sumatran orangutans, Sumatran tigers, Visayan warty pigs, Bali starlings and anoa and the threats they face.</p> </blockquote> <h2>Anoa facts</h2> <ul>     <li>The anoa, named after the Sulawesi word for buffalo, is a wild cattle species native to forests in Indonesia. This miniature water buffalo, which barely reach a metre in height, is divided into lowland and mountain species although there is still some debate as to whether they are in fact different</li>     <li>They are the smallest species of wild cattle </li>     <li>They live in forests and swamps on the Indonesian island of Sulawesi</li>     <li>Lowland anoa, as the name suggests, can be found in low-lying regions of swampy forest</li>     <li>They are listed as an endangered species by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN), meaning they face a very high risk of extinction in the wild </li>     <li>It is estimated that less than 2,500 mature individuals remain </li>     <li>Numbers have been declining throughout Sulawesi as a result of hunting for their meat and habitat loss, with forest being converted to agriculture, namely rice paddies </li>     <li>Very little is known about the ecology and life history of the anoas</li>     <li>The species is solitary, secret and silent and live alone or in pairs, rather than herds. Being able to stay silent as a solitary animal is safer in the forest than being part of a herd where disturbance is more likely and cover blown</li>     <li>They are browsers, feeding on vegetation </li>     <li>They are reported to drink seawater, which may be a source of minerals</li>     <li>Their distinctive flattened horns are a formidable weapon</li>     <li>Chester Zoo&rsquo;s new female calf was born on 22/10/2014. Keepers have called her Lasola after a river in Sulawesi</li>     <li>Mum is called Oana and is three years old (born on 4/5/2011)</li>     <li>Dad is called Bubba and is 17 (born 14/12/1997)</li> </ul> <h2>About Islands</h2> <ul>     <li>Islands is a &pound;30 million development project - the biggest and most ambitious zoo project in UK history</li>     <li>Work on Islands began in August 2013</li>     <li>It is set to open in spring 2015</li>     <li>Currently one of the biggest construction sites in the UK</li>     <li>Visitors will move through recreations of habitats in the Philippines, Bali, Sulawesi, Papua, Sumba and Sumatra, walking through different levels, travelling in boats and seeing buildings just like the real thing. It will create the feeling of an expedition and make visitors feel like they&rsquo;re following in the footsteps of the great explorers</li>     <li>42,000 plants be used to recreate the environments of the six different islands</li>     <li>The flagship indoor building that will be part of Islands will be called the Monsoon Forest &ndash; the largest indoor zoo exhibit in the UK. It will be totally unique in this country and will feature free flight birds, Sumatran orangutans, macaques and crocodiles</li>     <li>Other animals include anoa, banteng, babirusa, Bali starling, cassowary, Indonesian rhinoceros hornbill, Indonesian wrinkled hornbill, lorikeet, Sumatran tiger and the Visayan warty pig</li>     <li>The zoo hopes that by showcasing animals like this, then visitors seeing animals in an even more naturalistic setting than ever before, will make more of an emotional connection with them. If people care about a species they&rsquo;re more likely to help save them</li>     <li>Website: <a href="/islands/islands-news">www.chesterzoo.org/islands</a></li> </ul></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:02 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{F94625FB-16C3-49FD-A23F-B5430E60355F}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/spectacled-bear-lima-arrives</link><title>Lima the spectacled bear arrives at Chester Zoo </title><description><p>If you go down to Chester Zoo today you\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdre in for a big surprise. A new spectacled bear, named Lima, has arrived as part of the zoo\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds plans to breed the animals.</p><figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Spectacled bear" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/bears/Lima (6).ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <figcaption>Two-year-old spectacled bear Lima takes a stroll around her new enclosure at Chester Zoo. Lima has arrived from a zoo in northern France as part of the Europe breeding programme for the species, which is vulnerable to extinction in the wild.</figcaption> </figure> <p>Two-year-old Lima has moved from a zoo in northern France after experts carefully matched her with Chester&rsquo;s male bear, Bernardo.</p> <p>Spectacled bears are vulnerable to extinction in the wild and so staff at the zoo hope the pair will eventually go on to produce cubs, adding new blood to the insurance population living in zoos around the world.</p> <p>The bears, which are found in Venezuela, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru and Bolivia, are threatened by habitat loss; persecuted by local farmers for killing cattle and destroying crops and hunted for their meat, skin, bones, fat and claws. It is believed that only 20,000 now remain in the wild.</p> <p>In 2013 the zoo funded a project in Peru investigating the foraging behaviour of spectacled bears. The project ultimately aims to ensure the conservation of the species in the dry forest habitat of northern Peru through scientific research and education, while working collaboratively with private land owners and rural communities to improve their social and economic wellbeing.</p> <p>The arrival of Lima brings the number of spectacled bears living at the zoo to three.</p> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Spectacled bear at Chester ZOo" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/bears/Lima (11).ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <h2>Spectacled bear facts</h2> <ul>     <li>Spectacled bears get their name from the white or light rings of fur around their eyes, which can look like glasses (spectacles)</li>     <li>Spectacled bears are found in several areas of northern and western South America, including western Venezuela, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and western Bolivia</li>     <li>They are sometimes referred to as Andean bears, after the Andes mountains where some individuals are found</li>     <li>They are found in various habitats within the Andes Mountains, including desert-scrub, &lsquo;Paramo&rsquo; or high altitude grasslands and lush, misty cloud forests, ranging in elevation from 250 to 4,750 m</li>     <li>Males can grow up to 40% larger than females. Their head-body length ranges from 1.2 &ndash; 2 metres</li>     <li>Females weigh up to 84kg, males up to about 150kg</li>     <li>Spectacled bears are listed as vulnerable to extinction by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN)</li>     <li>There are only about 20,000 left in the wild</li>     <li>The main threats to the species are&nbsp;habitat fragmentation and destruction caused by livestock farming and logging is a major threat to this species. Spectacled bears are also persecuted by local farmers for killing cattle and destroying maize crops. Habitat fragmentation continues to bring bears and humans into closer proximity, leading to increased human-bear conflict</li>     <li>Though the hunting of spectacled bears is illegal, the species is still poached for its meat, skin, bones, fat and claws, which are all in demand locally. The gall bladders are occasionally marketed, being of value in traditional oriental medicine and can fetch a high price on the international market</li>     <li>Very little is known about these bears in the wild, as they are shy and tend to avoid humans, making them hard to find for researchers to study</li>     <li>Because of their tropical native climate, Andean bears do not hibernate and are active year-round</li>     <li>Chester Zoo&rsquo;s new female spectacled Lima was born on Jan 12, 2012</li>     <li>Lima has moved to Chester from Cerza Zoo in Lisieux, France as part of a breeding programme for the species</li>     <li>Chester Zoo is already home to male spectacled bear Bernardo and female Franka </li>     <li>Anyone who's read the children's stories about Paddington Bear will know he came from deepest darkest Peru. It means he was a spectacled bear because no other types of bear come from South America</li> </ul> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Bernardo - Spectacled bear at Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/bears/Bernardo (3).ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <figcaption>Male spectacled bear Bernardo enjoying the view from a tree in the enclosure.</figcaption> </figure></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:02 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{8C553DAB-D4A8-41E3-8722-6D44D27C0E43}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/tourism-investment-pledge</link><title>Deputy Prime Minister pledges \ufffd\ufffd10million investment in tourism strategy for the North</title><description><p>Chester Zoo today welcomed the pledge from Deputy Prime Minister Nick Clegg to invest \ufffd\ufffd10million in the development of a tourism strategy for the North.</p><p>In 2015, the zoo will open its <a href="/islands/islands-news">&pound;30million Islands project</a>, one of the biggest developments of its kind in the UK which will see an increase in visitors to the attraction, generating a wealth of new interest in the region.</p> <p>Jamie Christon, Managing Director, said:</p> <blockquote> <p>As one of the UK&rsquo;s leading tourist attractions and with one eye firmly on our future we welcome the additional funding for a North-focussed tourism strategy.</p> <p>The North has so much going for it. We already welcome 1.4 million visitors a year and Islands will bring many, many more. But a holistic approach to what the North can and does offer would be a very positive step forward for tourism growth and we look forward to seeing this strategy progress and to playing our part in it.</p> </blockquote> <p>Islands is one of the most ambitious projects in the history of UK zoos. Visitors will move through detailed recreations of habitats in the Philippines, Bali, Sulawesi, Papua, Sumba and Sumatra on their own personal conservation expedition.</p> <p><br /> </p> <div class="feature"> <div class="feature-inner"> <p><strong>DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER CALLS FOR STRATEGY TO BOOST TOURISM IN THE NORTH</strong></p> <p>&pound;10m of government money to back proposals for a clear strategy for tourism in the North, bringing harmony to the current offer from 29 individual tourism boards into one great offer.</p> <p><strong>In a nutshell</strong></p> <ul>     <li>London has 4.5 times more international visitors than the North of England as a whole. Scotland has twice as many tourists as Yorkshire or the entire North West.</li>     <li>London is not this country&rsquo;s only tourist destination &ndash; the North boasts stunning countryside, history and culture.</li>     <li>But how would anyone know that when there is no strategy for selling the North as a tourist destination. 30 per cent of UK visitors chose not to travel beyond London because they simply didn&rsquo;t know what there was to see outside the capital.</li>     <li>I launched a major project called Northern Futures &ndash; asking people in the North what our Northern cities needed in order to compete globally, and to grow.</li>     <li>I&rsquo;ve heard from businesses, local people, academics and council leaders. Your resounding call is clear - a strong Northern future relies on putting the North back on the map. Including making the region a top tourist destination with great transport, and thriving industry such as technology.</li>     <li>On the eve of the Northern Futures Summit I&rsquo;m responding to your calls for a coherent strategy for attracting tourists.</li>     <li>And that is why I&rsquo;m making available &pound;10m of government money to back proposals for a clear strategy for tourism in the North, bringing harmony to the current offer from 29 individual tourism boards into one great offer.</li>     <li>Creating a vision and plan will bring more visitors on holiday from at home and abroad to our great Northern cities. As the most senior member of the cabinet representing the North, I&rsquo;m passionate about the region. However, this isn&rsquo;t for Whitehall to deliver. It&rsquo;s important that this strategy is led by those already championing tourism in the North.</li>     <li>I&rsquo;m in Leeds hosting the Northern Futures Summit this Thursday to bring creative minds from across the North together so that we can grow more ideas like this into a reality.</li> </ul> <p><strong>Deputy Prime Minister, Nick Clegg said:</strong></p> <p>It&rsquo;s absurd that our great North is missing out on visitors when it boasts such stunning countryside, history and culture. Through the Northern Futures project, I asked people what our Northern cities needed in order to compete globally, and to grow.</p> <p>"Your resounding call is clear - a strong Northern future relies on putting the North back on the map: a top tourist destination. From next year, I&rsquo;m putting funding in place for there to be a clear strategy for tourism in the North, bringing harmony to the current offer from 29 individual tourism boards into one great offer.</p> <p><strong>Minister for Tourism Helen Grant said:</strong></p> <blockquote> <p>I grew up in Carlisle and know first-hand how important tourism is to the North of England. So I&rsquo;m passionate about championing the vibrant culture, fascinating heritage and stunning landscapes the north offers to tourists. </p> <p>This &pound;10 million fund will build on the success of the Government&rsquo;s tourism strategy to date, which has bought record numbers of visitors and spend to the UK. But we want to see a greater spread of tourism across the country and this will ensure that the North benefits from this element of our long term economic plan.</p> </blockquote> <p>We know there are a whole host of attractions across the North which are perfect hot spots for tourism. An industry which strengthens the economy and shows off the appeal of the North. And yet, every year, we see 4.5 times more visitors flocking to our capital city, than to the North. More people visited the British Museum than all tourist attractions in the North East put together last year.</p> <p>There are 9 guidebooks by one famous brand for different parts of Italy. There are just two by the same famous brand for Britain - London and Scotland. It&rsquo;s high time we create a harmonious offer to tourists for the North of England as a whole; putting our much loved Northern landmarks on the map and at the top of people&rsquo;s holiday wish lists.&nbsp;</p> <p>We want to see tourists planning visits to Penny Lane and the Beatles Museum in Liverpool, rather than automatically heading to the Abbey Road crossing. Taking in the impressive York Minster and the beauty of the Lake District, rather than thinking that Buckingham Palace defines British pomp.  Touring the ground of Alnwick Castle which was used as the exterior of Harry Potter&rsquo;s Hogwarts, instead of Windsor Castle seeming like the only option.&nbsp;</p> <p>So the question is <strong>how do we get people flying across the world to our great Northern cities?</strong></p> <p>Currently, there are 29 bodies pulling people to their individual localities in the North. In an age of one-stop-shop websites where people can compare holidays in Beirut to Bangalore, the North is sinking down the scoreboard.</p> <p>We won&rsquo;t get more people landing in the North on holiday with separate organisations competing against each other for visitors. However, if they work together with a joint vision and a strategy focusing on the best of the region, then we will have a whole much greater than the sum of its parts.</p> <p>Through the Northern Futures project, I&rsquo;ve listened to your ideas and thoughts on how we communicate the greatness of the North to build a stronger economy. It&rsquo;s clear we need tourism in the North to be a joint effort.&nbsp;</p> <p>So today I&rsquo;m calling for a strategy which will bring together the local knowledge of the 29 organisations, market the existing strengths of our Northern cities and pull together a plan for bringing more people to the North.&nbsp;</p> <p><strong>Why?</strong></p> <p><strong>Tourism efforts aren&rsquo;t joined up: </strong>If you were sitting in the US and wanted to book a holiday that explored Ancient Britain, taking in Hadrian&rsquo;s Wall, York&rsquo;s Viking history and the roman city of Chester, you&rsquo;d need to log on to 3 different visit websites.</p> <p><strong>People aren&rsquo;t visiting the North: </strong>The whole of the North only accounted for 22% of all visits to English tourist attractions.</p> <p><strong>How would we do it?</strong></p> <p>Subject to strong proposals, I will make available &pound;10 million from the Regional Growth Fund&not; for the development of a new strategy for tourism in the North. Ring-fenced funding will be channelled into the national tourist body for our country, Visit England, with support from the Department for Culture, Media and Sport. This will need to be matched by local funds to ensure potential tourists are provided with a compelling joined up picture of what&rsquo;s on offer in the North.</p> <p><strong>What does the North have to offer?</strong></p> <p>There is a cornucopia of attractions in the region, from the Lake District to the Peak District; from Penny Lane to Wilberforce House; Hadrian&rsquo;s Wall, Blackpool Tower, Bettys tea rooms Harrogate, the National Football Museum, York Minster, Durham cathedral, the MAGNA Science Centre, Castle Howard and the Angel of the North. The list of international attractions is almost endless. </p> </div> </div></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:02 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{25021BD1-4895-4A96-8AC1-42430FA11C94}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/dwarf-mongoose-pups-emerge</link><title>Dwarf mongoose pups emerge at Chester Zoo</title><description><p>Two dwarf mongoose pups born at Chester Zoo have taken tiny steps into the outside world. </p><p>The little youngsters, the smallest of all the African carnivores, were spotted by keepers enjoying their first adventure at the zoo.</p>  <div class="video">   <iframe frameborder="0" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/HJ1-2leC_Vc?rel=0"> </iframe> <div class="video-mask video-mask__top"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__right"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__bottom"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__left"></div> </div> <p>The duo spent a month in their nest box with keepers just hearing occasional squeaks.</p> <p>Twilight team manager Dave White said:</p> <blockquote> <p>Now that our new duo has started exploring they&rsquo;re going to keep mum, dad and the rest of the dwarf  mongoose group very much on their tiny toes.</p> <p>Dwarf mongoose are highly sociable animals, living in groups where each mongoose has a job to do. When a litter of young is born then the whole group helps to care for them, with females other than their mum even producing milk for them.</p> <p>They may be small but they&rsquo;re a fascinating species and what they lack in size they certainly make up for in likability.</p> </blockquote> <p>The arrival of the pups brings the number of <a href="/animals/mammals/meerkats_otters_mongooses/dwarf-mongoose">dwarf mongoose</a> at the zoo to nine but it&rsquo;s too early for keepers to be able to tell if the pups are male or female.</p> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Dwarf mongoose at Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/meerkat_otter_mongoose/dwarf-mongoose/Mongoose-1 (2).ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Dwarf mongoose - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/meerkat_otter_mongoose/dwarf-mongoose/Mongoose-9.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <h2>Dwarf mongoose facts</h2> <ul>     <li>Dwarf mongoose are found in many parts of Africa, living in woodlands, grasslands and rocky outcrops</li>     <li>They mainly feed on locusts, beetles, spiders, termites, grubs and mealworms, smaller mammals like mice, small birds, lizards and snakes</li>     <li>They are Africa&rsquo;s smallest carnivore, as well as the smallest of the mongoose species</li>     <li>Adult dwarf mongoose only grow to about 30cm (12 inches)</li>     <li>Mongoose live in groups led by an alpha female and her male partner</li>     <li>Dwarf mongoose are related to meerkats</li>     <li>The group has a social structure with each mongoose having a job to do. One of the most important of these jobs is that of the lookout who keeps a check on what's going on around and about</li>     <li>The dominant pair of the group tend to produce a litter of young each year which the rest of the group help to care for, with subordinate females even producing milk for them</li>     <li>They make short chirrup sounds to communicate with each other</li>     <li>The two new youngsters were born on 08/09/14</li>     <li>Keepers do not yet know the pups&rsquo; gender and so they&rsquo;ve not yet been named</li> </ul> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Dwarf mongoose pups emerge - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/meerkat_otter_mongoose/dwarf-mongoose/Mongoose-6 (2).ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:02 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{1950AFA5-B521-4E63-8D41-944231C2652E}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/rhino-arrives-new-breeding-plan</link><title>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdImportant rhino\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd arrives in new Chester Zoo breeding plan </title><description><p>A new rhino, which has arrived at Chester Zoo from Germany, will be leading the charge as the zoo gears up for more successful breeding of the rare species. </p><figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Black rhino at Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/horses-and-rhinos/black-rhino/Rhino-8.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <figcaption>BREEDING CHARGE: Kifaru, a 29-year-old Eastern black rhino, is settling in to his new surroundings at Chester Zoo after moving from Hannover Zoo in Germany. It is hoped that Kifaru will sire a number of new calves and bring vital new blood to the European population of Eastern black rhinos &ndash; a species classed by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) as critically endangered in the wild.</figcaption> </figure> <p>Twenty-nine-year-old Kifaru - an Eastern black rhino - is settling in to his new home after travelling from Hannover Zoo.&nbsp;</p> <p>Staff in Chester hope their new arrival will sire a number of new calves and bring vital new blood to the European population of Eastern black rhinos &ndash; a species classed by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) as critically endangered in the wild.</p> <p>He will soon be introduced to the zoo&rsquo;s current females, starting with Ema Elsa.</p> <p>The zoo&rsquo;s curator of mammals, Tim Rowlands, said:</p> <blockquote> <p>With a species that&rsquo;s as highly threatened with extinction as the Eastern black rhino, all individuals in the European breeding programme are important.</p> <p>As so few individuals exist, it is essential that we achieve successful breeding from as many of the rhinos in zoos as possible. Kifaru has only sired three calves previously; this means he has a great opportunity to add to the dwindling numbers of black rhino which makes him one of the most important rhinos around. Any offspring he may go on to produce here would bring vital genetics to the European population.&nbsp;</p> <p>This population is vital as an insurance policy against further declines in the wild and the more successful the population is, the better that insurance policy can be.</p> <p>We have one of the best records in the world when it comes to breeding rhinos, so fingers crossed we can encourage Kifaru to work his magic with our females.</p> </blockquote> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Black rhino - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/horses-and-rhinos/black-rhino/Rhino-2.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p>There are now thought to be less than 650 Eastern black rhinos remaining in the wild, placing the species perilously close to extinction.</p> <p>Numbers in Africa have plummeted as a result of a dramatic surge in illegal poaching. A global increase in demand for rhino horn to supply the traditional Asian medicine market, where it is wrongly believed to be a cure for everything from nightmares to dysentery, has intensified the situation in recent times.</p> <p>Emerging markets in Vietnam and an upsurge in the supply of arms used to hunt rhino, have further added to the problem. This attrition is being driven by the astonishing street value for rhino horn, which fetches &pound;40,000 a kilo - more than gold.</p> <p>Chester Zoo has long supported conservation efforts in the wild to try and protect black rhinos and continues to pump money, and provide expertise, to numerous projects in Africa.&nbsp;</p> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Black rhino - breeding programme at Chester Zoo " src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/horses-and-rhinos/black-rhino/Rhino-7.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p><br /> </p> <h2>Notes to editors</h2> <ul>     <li>Eastern black rhino are listed as critically endangered by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN)</li>     <li>The current number of Eastern black rhino in the wild is less than 650. This is 90% lower than three generations ago &ndash; largely a result of a dramatic surge in illegal poaching</li>     <li>There are 313 black rhino (made up on two subspecies, <em>D. b. michaeli</em> (264) and <em>D. b. minor </em>(49)) in captivity worldwide according to the international studbook 2013&nbsp;</li>     <li>Dr. Mark Pilgrim, Chester Zoo&rsquo;s director general, co-ordinates the European breeding programme for one of the subspecies of black rhino (<em>D. b. michaeli</em>)  of which there are 62 held in zoos in Europe (10% of the total wild population of this sub-species, Eastern black rhino). This population is an insurance population for their wild relatives</li>     <li>Helping to ensure an insurance population exists in the event that black rhino become extinct in the wild, Chester Zoo has been successful in breeding a number of critically endangered black rhinos and plays a vital part in the international breeding programme</li>     <li>In 2007, Chester Zoo established its Wildlife Endocrinology Laboratory. Endocrinology is an important tool in Chester Zoo&rsquo;s mission to conserve biodiversity. When animals fail to thrive or breed, clues can generally be found through hormone assessment. Hormones associated with reproduction and adrenal function are easily measured non-invasively in urine and faeces. Its role is to enhance the well-being and reproductive success of threatened species, both in zoos and in the wild. This ground-breaking science has helped to achieve a rhino baby boom at the zoo in recent years, with four black rhino calves born in the space of just four years&nbsp;</li>     <li>Chester Zoo has long supported conservation efforts in the wild to try and protect black rhinos and continues to pump money, and provide expertise, to numerous projects in Africa</li>     <li>People can help to protect wild rhinos by donating to <a href="http://www.actforwildlife.org.uk/black-rhinos/black-rhinos">Chester Zoo&rsquo;s Act for Wildlife rhino project</a>, where 100% of the money donated is used at conservation projects in the wild.</li>      </ul></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:02 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{C480F19A-BE50-4477-8770-96D3792AB694}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/sand-lizards-reintroduced</link><title>UK\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds rarest lizards return to sand dunes</title><description><p>Keepers and conservationists at Chester Zoo join breeding and reintroduction efforts to help boost sand lizard numbers</p><div class="video">   <iframe frameborder="0" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/X9nFWekX5xY?rel=0"> </iframe> <div class="video-mask video-mask__top"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__right"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__bottom"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__left"></div> </div> <p>Rare lizards, which were believed to have gone extinct in Wales around 60 years ago, have been released on sand dunes in the north of the country in a bid to boost struggling populations.&nbsp;</p> <p>The sand lizards - an endangered UK species - were bred at a number of specialist breeding centres, including Chester Zoo, during the summer.</p> <p>The species has gone through major decline due to habitat loss, with their coastal dune and heathland habitats becoming increasingly fragmented by agricultural expansion and building developments.</p> <p>But a captive breeding and reintroduction programme is now helping the lizards to make a comeback at a site in Talacre, North Wales.&nbsp;</p>  <p><img alt="Keeper Ruth Smith - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/Keeper Ruth Smith helps return 31 sand lizards to North Wales.ashx" style="font-size: 12px; line-height: 15.600000381469727px;" /></p> <p>Herpetology keeper Ruth Smith said:</p> <blockquote> <p>Sand lizards are the UK&rsquo;s rarest lizard and populations in some areas are so low that we can&rsquo;t just rely on protecting the site, we have to help breed them to boost their numbers.</p> <p>Surveys have shown that sand lizard numbers have significantly improved in the locations where they have been released before and it&rsquo;s proven that those bred in the likes of zoos have a higher chance of survival than those that hatch in the wild. That&rsquo;s because we&rsquo;re able to give them plenty of food and intensive care in their vital early days and build them up for around four to six weeks, giving them a great head start.&nbsp;</p> <p>This year we&rsquo;ve reintroduced 31 juvenile lizards to the wild - a record for the zoo so we&rsquo;re really pleased.&nbsp;</p> <p>Slowly and surely we&rsquo;re getting them back into areas where historically they used to live.</p> </blockquote> <p><img alt="Sand lizards" src="/~/media/news/2014/SandLizards2-46.ashx" /></p> <p>Chester Zoo has been involved with the sand lizard reintroduction programme since it began in 1994, hatching lizards on a replica sand dune at the zoo and rearing them up for release. The sand dune replica uses plants licensed from nature reserves to replicate their natural environment.</p> <p>The zoo is working on the release with a number of volunteers, as well Natural England, the Herpetological Conservation Trust, the Amphibian and Reptile Conservation charity (ARC) and Natural Resources Wales (NRW).</p> <h2>Sand lizard facts&nbsp;</h2> <ul>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">The sand lizard was once commonly found on dunes and heathland in Britain but the gradual destruction of its habitats has led to its extinction in many places</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">According to the Amphibian and Reptile Conservation group (ARC), the lizard was lost altogether from a number of counties including Cheshire, Cornwall, Kent, Sussex, and north and west Wales</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">More than 90% of suitable habitat has also vanished from Merseyside, Surrey and Dorset</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">During the breeding season male sand lizards adopt a bright green colouration to attract a mate. Females are often a sandy brown colour&nbsp;</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">The sand lizard is Britain&rsquo;s only egg-laying lizard. The females lay eggs in burrows dug in the sand in June or July, before they hatch a couple of months later</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Sand lizards are the UK&rsquo;s biggest lizard species and adults can reach 20cm in length</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Sand lizards tend to hibernate between November and March, but can be seen basking on rocks in sandy heathland and dunes during the summer</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Its scientific name is Lacerta agilis</span></li> </ul> <div><br /> </div></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:02 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{51A2B7B9-5264-475F-891A-854EE48A19D1}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/critically-endangered-ducklings-hatch-at-chester-zoo</link><title>Critically endangered ducklings hatch at Chester Zoo</title><description><p>A rare species of Asian duck, which is on the brink of extinction, has been bred at Chester Zoo. Keepers believe as many Baer\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds pochard ducklings have hatched at Chester Zoo this year as are now left in the wild.</p><p><img alt="" src="/~/media/Images/Press and Media/Image Gallery/Ducklings-12.ashx?h=470&amp;w=750" /></p> <p>Thirty Baer&rsquo;s pochard ducklings have hatched &ndash; with a similar number living in the wild.&nbsp;</p> <p>The species is listed by the International Union for the Conservation Nature (IUCN) as critically endangered as a result of hunting and loss of their habitat in Siberia and eastern Asia where they were once commonly found in their tens of thousands. Experts fear just a few individuals are now left and the species could soon vanish altogether.</p> <p>Curator of Birds Andrew Owen said:</p> <blockquote> <p>We&rsquo;re perilously close to losing this species in the wild and that&rsquo;s why our recent hatchlings are very, very important&nbsp;indeed. They&rsquo;re without doubt some of the rarest ducks in the world.</p> <p> Thirty Baer&rsquo;s pochards have been bred here this breeding season and whilstit&rsquo;s good news in the sense that it&rsquo;s a record for us, rather frighteningly, there may only be similar numbers left in the wild.</p> </blockquote> <p>Chester Zoo is one of just a handful of institutions in the world &ndash; and the only zoo in the UK - that is working with the highly threatened species and hopes to play a vital role in their long-term survival.</p> <p>Mr Owen added:</p> <blockquote> <p>Our very talented bird team have given all our ducklings a helping hand, rearing them under close watch to make sure they make it through to adulthood. With a species that&rsquo;s so rare, it&rsquo;s imperative that we get as many through to that stage as possible.</p> <p>Hopefully these little ducklings will start to rear their own young next year and, beyond that, a European-wide breeding programme in zoos and bird parks could be what saves the species from extinction.</p> </blockquote> <p><img alt="" src="/~/media/Images/Press and Media/Image Gallery/Ducks-11.ashx?h=499&amp;w=750" /> </p> <p> </p> <h2>Baer&rsquo;s pochard facts</h2> <p>The Baer&rsquo;s pochard is a diving duck found in eastern Asia. It spends the summer in southeast Russia and northeast China, migrating in winter to southern China, Vietnam, Japan and India.</p> <p>The species breeds in the wild on marshy ponds in southeast Russia and northeast China, migrating in winter to southern China, Vietnam, Japan, and India.</p> <p>They dive up to a depth of 2 m to hunt aquatic insects, molluscs, shrimps and fishes. They also eat algae, aquatic plants and seeds, especially during winter.</p> <p>Chester Zoo is one of the few one of the few institutions in Europe to currently work with this rare diving duck.</p> <p>The species is listed by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) as critically endangered. They are threatened due to habitat loss, illegal poisoning and trapping.</p></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:02 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{53F7AD3D-E6F5-42E1-BFC9-F8D1F9B429D8}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/wildlife-survey-at-chester-zoo</link><title>Volunteer to help with a 24 hour wildlife survey</title><description><p>Staff at Chester Zoo are used to keeping a tally of their lions, tigers and other exotic animals. But now they are looking for help to add up some of the many UK wildlife species that reside inside the zoo\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds grounds.</p><p><img alt="" src="/~/media/news/2014/BugClub-31.ashx?h=666&amp;w=1001" /></p> <p>The special survey &ndash; labelled by conservationists as a BioBlitz &ndash; will look to find as many species which are native to the UK as possible, in a 24 hour period.</p> <p>And the zoo is looking for volunteers to help experts with the count.</p> <p>Sarah Bazley, zoo ranger team manager, said:</p> <blockquote>We need a host of volunteers who fancy becoming a wildlife scientist for the day, to help us make a record of the diversity in and around the zoo. No experience is required, just a willing attitude and a keen eye. They will help find creatures such as great green bush crickets, wolf spiders, elephant hawk-moths and wood mice and maybe nocturnal visitors like badgers, owls and bats.<span style="line-height: 1.3;">&rdquo;</span></blockquote> <p><span style="line-height: 1.3;">The survey, which will take on September 6 and September 7, is part of the 2014 British and Irish Association of Zoos and Aquariums (BIAZA) BioBlitz which will see lots of other UK zoos doing the same during the month of September.</span></p> <p><span style="line-height: 1.3;">To book a place one to one of two available sessions (Saturday Sept 6, noon-4pm and Sunday Sept 7, 6am-noon) or find out more please contact the zoo via </span><a href="mailto:learning@chesterzoo.org" style="line-height: 1.3;">learning@chesterzoo.org</a><span style="line-height: 1.3;"> or 01244 650205.</span></p> <p><strong style="line-height: 1.3;"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Notes</span></strong></p> <p>A BioBlitz is a large scale event that engages large numbers of people with biodiversity, inviting them to get directly involved in surveying and monitoring</p> <p><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Chester Zoo&rsquo;s BioBlitz is suitable for those aged 12 and above. Children aged between 12-15 must be supervised by a parent or guardian</span></p> <p>Around 40 volunteers are required, split between two sessions:</p> <p><strong>Saturday 6th September: 12noon &ndash; 4pm</strong>, looking at botany and Invertebrates (aquatic and terrestrial)</p> <p><strong>Sunday 7th September: 6am &ndash; 12noon</strong>, looking at early birds and mammals at the zoo&rsquo;s nature reserve</p> <p>Places are limited and so booking is essential</p> <p>To book a place or to find out more, please contact the zoo via<a href="mailto:learning@chesterzoo.org?subject=learning@chesterzoo.org"> </a><a href="mailto:learning@chesterzoo.org">learning@chesterzoo.org</a> or 01244 650205</p> <p>BIAZA BioBlitz is an annual event organised by our Native Species Working Group (NWSG) in conjunction with the Bristol Natural History Consortium (BNHC)</p> <p><strong style="line-height: 1.3;"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">About Chester Zoo</span></strong></p> <p>Chester Zoo is a registered conservation charity that supports projects around the world and in the UK. Welcoming 1.4 million visitors a year, it is the largest zoo in the UK; home to 11,000 animals, over 400 different species, many of which are endangered</p> <p>Through its wildlife conservation campaign, Act for Wildlife, the zoo is helping to save highly threatened species around the world from extinction. Find out more at&nbsp;<a href="http://www.chesterzoo.org/www.actforwildlife.org.uk">www.actforwildlife.org.uk</a></p></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:02 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{8CB8DDE0-D17B-4B1C-B3B6-FA0E64D9F076}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/hormone-analysis-helps-identify-horny-rhinos</link><title>Hormone analysis helps identify horny rhinos</title><description><p>The first comprehensive study of black rhino reproduction in European zoos highlights how hormone analysis could improve the success of breeding programmes.</p><figure> <p class="figure-image-wrapper"><strong style="font-size: 12px; line-height: 1.3;"><img alt="" src="/~/media/Images/Press and Media/Image Gallery/Rhino-2.ashx?h=506&amp;w=800" /></strong></p> <p class="figure-image-wrapper"><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Researchers from Chester Zoo, The University of Manchester and The University of Liverpool carried out a six-year study which encompassed 90% of European population of black rhino.</span></p> <p class="figure-image-wrapper"><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Dr Katie Edwards led the research as part of her PhD at The University of Liverpool. She says: &ldquo;Although some black rhinoceros breed well in zoos, not all do therefore reducing the vital genetic reserve that these populations represent. This species is of high conservation importance, so understanding what could be limiting breeding in certain individuals and how we could make improvements is a priority.&rdquo;</span></p> <p class="figure-image-wrapper"><span style="line-height: 1.3;">In total 9743 samples from 11 zoos were sent to Chester Zoo&rsquo;s Wildlife Endocrinology laboratory to analyse female reproductive cycles.</span></p> <p class="figure-image-wrapper"><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Dr Edwards says: &ldquo;Our analyses showed that females who had never bred were more likely to exhibit irregular oestrous cycles, indicating that underlying physiology is involved in differences in breeding success.&rdquo;</span></p>  <p class="figure-image-wrapper"><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Dr Edwards continues:  <blockquote>&ldquo;As well as non-breeding females not cycling as reliably, behavioural observations showed us that these females don't necessarily show when they are ready to mate, which can make managing breeding difficult. Hormone analysis helps address this problem by allowing us to predict when a female will be sexually receptive to a male, even if she doesn&rsquo;t make it obvious.</span></p> </blockquote>  <p class="figure-image-wrapper"><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Hormone analysis has been successfully used at Chester Zoo which has seen three births in the last three years.</span></p> <p class="figure-image-wrapper"><span style="line-height: 1.3;">As well as looking at hormone analysis, the researchers also investigated a number of other factors that could affect breeding success.</span></p> <p class="figure-image-wrapper"><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Females that had never bred were found to be heavier than those that had, demonstrating that maintaining a suitable diet in zoos can play an important role in the success of breeding programmes.</span></p> <p class="figure-image-wrapper"><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Non-breeding females were also found to be more unpredictable in their overall temperaments.</span></p> <p class="figure-image-wrapper"><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Dr Susanne Shultz from the Faculty of Life Sciences at The University of Manchester was the academic supervisor for the project. She says: &ldquo;This research highlights how rhinos can behave in a different manner despite being kept in similar conditions. We think this demonstrates that it is important to recognise individual differences and adjust management plans accordingly to maximise the health and reproduction across all individuals in the population."</span></p> <p class="figure-image-wrapper"><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Dr Sue Walker, Head of Applied Science at Chester Zoo, oversaw the project.</span><strong style="line-height: 1.3;"> </strong><span style="line-height: 1.3;">She concludes:   <blockquote>&ldquo;Poaching in the wild is a serious threat to the rhino; therefore it is important for us to understand the factors that can influence reproductive success. We established the project to understand why some individuals breed well, while others do not. The idea is that with a better understanding of factors that affect reproduction, we know where we should be focusing our efforts to support the European-wide breeding programme for this critically endangered species.&rdquo;</blockquote></span></p> <p class="figure-image-wrapper"><span style="line-height: 1.3;">The results of the study have been published in the Journal of General and Comparative Endocrinology.</span></p> </figure><figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:02 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{665ACA4A-F235-4F78-81E1-CE8A3457D5F7}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/tickled-pink-flamingo-chicks</link><title>Chester Zoo has welcomed some new additions to its flamingo flock.</title><description><p>The Chilean flamingo chicks started to hatch on July 18 with 13 more arriving since then.</p><figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="" src="/~/media/pr-folder/Flamingo-1.ashx?h=640&amp;w=445" style="line-height: 1.3;" /></div> <figcaption>Flamingo chicks debut at Chester Zoo</figcaption> </figure> <div style="font-weight: bold;"><strong><br /> </strong></div> Curator of birds, Andrew Owen, said:<br /> <blockquote> &ldquo;Their trademark pink feathers won&rsquo;t start to show for about six months - instead the chicks have a mix of grey and white feathers. They&rsquo;re like fluffy tennis balls with legs at the moment.<br /> <br /> &ldquo;After initially staying really close to their parents, the chicks are now gaining in confidence and some have even started to wade in the water around their island.<br /> <br /> &ldquo;It has been a very successful breeding season for us and we&rsquo;re very pleased with these new arrivals.<br /> <br /> &ldquo;They&rsquo;re a particularly interesting species as it&rsquo;s not yet known whether or not Chilean flamingos choose different mates over the course of their lives or for how long they breed for. So our group, including our newcomers, are part of a long-term study looking into these sorts of things. This kind of information can then be passed on to help conservationists in the wild and help protect the long term future of the species.&rdquo; <br /> <br /> </blockquote> Despite their name, Chilean flamingos are not just found in Chile. They also live in Argentina, Bolivia and Ecuador where they reside mainly on estuaries, lagoons, mud flats and salt lakes.<br /> <br /> The species is classed as a near threatened species &ndash; meaning they are likely to become endangered and threatened with a high risk of extinction in the wild in the near future. Habitat loss and poaching of their eggs are blamed for a decrease in their numbers. <br /> <br /> Chester Zoo&rsquo;s flock of Chilean flamingos, which has been at the zoo since the 1960s, now numbers 112.<figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p><br /> </p> <h2>Flamingo facts&nbsp;</h2> <ul>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;"></span>     </li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">There are about 200,000-300,000 Chilean flamingos in the wild where continued monitoring of their numbers is vital as they have long been a target of poachers who pinch their eggs. This, along with a loss of habitat as developers and farmers move into areas where they live, has put the flamboyant species under increasing threat</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">They live mainly on estuaries, lagoons, mud flats and salt lakes</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Salmon pink coloured with grey legs and pink knees, they are closely related to Caribbean Flamingos, which are also found at Chester Zoo, but the Chilean birds are paler in colour</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">They get their colour from crustaceans and algae that they eat</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Chilean flamingos are classed by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) as a near threatened species &ndash; meaning they are likely to become endangered and threatened with a high risk of extinction in the wild in the near future</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">The word flamingo comes from the Spanish and Latin word &lsquo;flamenco&rsquo;, meaning fire</span></li> </ul></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:02 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{F6A86942-2ED3-4AD3-8587-32A370C8AD47}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/red-panda-cubs-health-check</link><title>Red panda cubs have their first health check-up at Chester Zoo</title><description><p>A rare red panda cub is given the once over by keepers at Chester Zoo. </p><figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Red panda" src="/~/media/news/2014/RedPandas-31.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p>The cub is one of two to have been born at the zoo where keepers say they were alerted to their arrival after hearing &ldquo;little squeaks&rdquo; from a nest box.&nbsp;</p> <p>The twins, a boy and a girl, were born on June 27 to first-time mum Nima and dad Jung but keepers have only now been able to get a good look at them for the first time.&nbsp;</p> <p>Keeper Maxine Bradley said:&nbsp;</p> <blockquote> <p>Our two cubs are in very good shape. They&rsquo;re big and strong with very thick fur - our male weighed in at just under 1kg and our female 842g.</p> <p>We&rsquo;re really pleased with how well they&rsquo;re doing and, as soon as we had given them a health check, we popped them back into their nest. It&rsquo;ll be several weeks until they start to emerge and explore. &nbsp;</p> </blockquote> <p>Red pandas, whose scientific name <em>Ailurus fulgens</em> means &lsquo;brilliant cat&rsquo;, are native to the steep forested slopes of the Himalayas. They are a one-of-a-kind in the animal kingdom as they have no close living relatives.&nbsp;</p> <p>Conservation experts have listed them as endangered in the wild, as they are threatened by poaching and shrinking habitat. .</p> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Red Panda at Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/other/red-panda/RedPandas-2.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:03 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{D23A4D7F-523B-4755-B4BC-BDDF04FF9B81}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/rare-african-crane-chicks</link><title>Rare African crane chicks hatch at Chester Zoo </title><description><p>New arrivals are first to arrive in the UK this year</p><figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Black-crowned crane at Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/birds/cranes/black-crowned-crane/black-crowned-crane800.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <figcaption>A new West African black-crowned crane mum keeps a beady eye on her young offspring as it takes its first few steps at Chester Zoo. The little crane is one of two to have hatched at the zoo &ndash; the first in a UK zoo this year</figcaption> </figure> <p>Two rare birds have hatched at Chester Zoo.</p> <p>The West African black-crowned crane chicks are the first of their kind to hatch in a UK zoo this year and arrived after a 30 day incubation period.</p> <div class="video">   <iframe frameborder="0" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/ZP3PbV4a16A?rel=0"> </iframe> <div class="video-mask video-mask__top"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__right"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__bottom"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__left"></div> </div>  <p>Curator of birds, Andrew Owen, said:</p> <blockquote> <p>This is a very significant breeding &ndash; the first in the UK this year.&nbsp;</p> <p>Currently the chicks are small, yellow and fluffy and it&rsquo;s hard to believe that they&rsquo;ll grow up to look as striking and unusual as mum and dad. But soon enough they&rsquo;ll develop golden feathers on top of their heads that almost resemble a Roman helmet. Already the young are very confident and capable of foraging with their parents.</p> <p>Cranes are also known for their elaborate dances and our young chicks are already capable of some nifty moves!</p> </blockquote> <p>West African black-crowed cranes are listed as vulnerable to extinction by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN), with just 15,000 estimated to remain in the wild. The birds&rsquo; range spans from Senegal to Chad but its habitat is under threat due to drainage, overgrazing and pesticide pollution. The capture and trade of the species is also having a dramatic effect on wild numbers.</p> <p>Mr Owen added:</p> <blockquote> <p>As well as suffering from habitat loss and poisoning by farmers, black-crowned cranes are also caught and used as &lsquo;guard dogs&rsquo;. They are also disappearing as they hit newly installed overhead power lines. This all means that sadly, these birds are now very rare in the wild.&nbsp;</p> </blockquote> <p>Chester Zoo has supported initiatives to assist in the conservation of black crowned cranes in coastal areas of West Africa<span style="line-height: 1.3;">.</span></p> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Black-crowned crane born at Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/birds/cranes/black-crowned-crane/Cranes-43.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <h2>West African black-crowned crane facts&nbsp;</h2> <ul>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">The chicks hatched at Chester Zoo on 19/07/14</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Dad was born on 15/08/2002 and is nearly 12 years old. He was the first parent-reared crane to hatch at the zoo</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Mum was born 03/09/1998 and is nearly 16 years old</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">West African crowned cranes are monogamous and remain and couple for life. Both the male and female build their nest together and take turns in incubating eggs and caring for the young</span></li> </ul></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:03 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{EB18A456-37A6-45DF-8C11-CBE77EDCAFEB}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/little-humbug-born</link><title>Adorable \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdlittle humbug\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd born at Chester Zoo</title><description><p>Zookeepers at Chester Zoo have announced the birth of a baby tapir.</p><figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Baby tapir at Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/tapir/baby-tapir/Tapir-16.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <figcaption>Little humbug! Three-day-old tapir Zathras makes his public debut at Chester Zoo</figcaption> </figure> <p>The tiny calf was born on Monday at 11am to mum Jenny after a gestation period of around 13 months. The new youngster &ndash; the first male to be born at the zoo for eight years - has already been given the name Zathras.&nbsp;</p> <p>Curator of mammals, Tim Rowlands, said:</p> <blockquote> <p>Our new calf, Zathras, was up and about really quickly and he and mum are doing fine. Jenny is an experienced mum and she&rsquo;s doing a top job.</p> <p>At the moment Zathras looks a bit like a little humbug. His brown coat currently features lots of white stripes and spots which will eventually disappear as he gets to around six-to-nine months old. The markings act as camouflage in the wild &ndash; mimicking speckled sunlight on the forest floor. He won&rsquo;t be little for long though as new youngsters tend to double their weight in the first 14-21 days alone.</p> </blockquote> <p>Chester Zoo, which was named as the best zoo in the UK in a recent Trip Advisor poll, has enjoyed good breeding successes with tapirs in the past - including Zathras&rsquo;s 22-year-old dad Cuzco who was also born at the zoo.</p> <p>In the wild Brazilian, or lowland, tapirs live in wet forests and grasslands in South America where they are threatened because of habitat destruction and hunting. They are classed as vulnerable to extinction by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN).</p> <p>Chester Zoo is a keen supporter of a conservation initiative which has been finding out valuable information about behaviour patterns and movements of tapirs in several key areas of Brazil.</p> <p>It is hoped this research will help safeguard the future of the fascinating species which is increasingly hunted for its meat and for its hide, which is used to make sandals.</p> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Baby tapir at Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/tapir/baby-tapir/Tapir-35.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p><br /> </p> <h2>Tapir facts&nbsp;</h2> <ul>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">New baby Zathras was born at 11am on 04/08/2014&nbsp;</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Mum is called Jenny who was born on 24/07/1992. She is 22 years old&nbsp;</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Dad is called Cuzco who was born on 03/10/1991. He is also 22 years old</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Lowland tapirs live in several different South American Countries, including Argentina, Brazil, Peru, Paraguay, Venezuela and Bolivia</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Young are weaned at around four months old but they will double their weight in the first 14-21 days&nbsp;</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Adult tapirs are around two metres in length and stand about three foot high</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">They live on a diet of fruits, berries and leaves</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Their closest relatives are horses and rhinoceroses</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">They are excellent swimmers</span></li> </ul> <p><br /> </p></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:03 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{8AEB6458-9AEE-4EC0-858E-E928C9703B6D}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/chester-zoo-named-best-zoo-uk</link><title>Chester Zoo named Europe's second best zoo in TripAdvisor Travellers' Choice Attractions Awards</title><description><p>Chester Zoo also rated sixth best zoo in the world and the UK\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds number one, according to millions of traveller reviews and opinions</p><figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Spectacled bear" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/bears/Bernie1 Custom.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <figcaption>Spectacled bear at Chester Zoo</figcaption> </figure> <p>Chester Zoo has today been named as the best rated zoo in the UK in the Travellers&rsquo; Choice&trade;&nbsp;awards for Zoos and Aquariums, announced by TripAdvisor, the world&rsquo;s largest travel site*.</p> <p>The Cheshire zoo, which is home to over 11,000 animals of over 400 species set in 110 acres of zoological gardens, is also named second best rated zoo in Europe and sixth in the world.</p> <p>Jamie Christon, managing director of Chester Zoo said:</p> <blockquote> <p>We&rsquo;re absolutely delighted to have received the seal of approval from the public and named the best zoo in the UK and indeed one of the very best in the world.&nbsp;</p> <p>Our sincere thanks go to every single person that has come here because, as a registered charity, their visits help us to carry out all of our vital conservation work &ndash; saving species from extinction both here in the UK and overseas.</p> </blockquote> <p>It&rsquo;s not just Cheshire that has cause to celebrate this year; the awards reveal that the UK is home to more award-winning zoos in 2014 than any other European country, with eight zoos ranked in Europe&rsquo;s top 25. Chester Zoo in Cheshire, Colchester Zoo in Essex, Paignton Zoo Environmental Park in Devon, Folly Farm Adventure Park and Zoo in South Wales, Blackpool Zoo in Lancashire, Durrell Wildlife Park in Jersey, Cotswold Wildlife Park and Gardens in Oxfordshire and Knowsley Safari in Merseyside take second, eighth, ninth, thirteenth, fourteenth, twenty-first, twenty-second and twenty-fifth respectively.</p> <p>The UK also boasts three winners among the world&rsquo;s top 25 &ndash; second only to the US, which claims the most world winners with nine.</p> <p>Within the UK, it is the North West that takes the lead with more TripAdvisor Travellers&rsquo; Choice Awards for Zoos than anywhere else in the country. Chester Zoo in Cheshire, Blackpool Zoo in Lancashire, Knowsley Safari in Liverpool and South Lakes Safari Zoo in Dalton-in-Furness take first, fifth, eighth and ninth place in the UK respectively.</p> <p>&ldquo;These awards are based on the millions of reviews and opinions written by our global community of travellers, so if you&rsquo;re looking for some inspiration for a great family day out, the UK winners are a great addition to your summer holidays hit list,&rdquo; commented TripAdvisor spokesperson, James Kay.</p> <p>Nebraska&rsquo;s Henry Doorly Zoo in the United States earns the coveted position of number one zoo in the world.</p> <p><strong>Honour for Hull as aquarium is named in European top 10</strong></p> <p>In the aquariums category, The Deep in the Yorkshire city of Hull is revealed as the ninth best aquarium in Europe. National Marine Aquarium in Plymouth and Lyme Regis Marine Aquarium in Dorset also rank in Europe&rsquo;s top 25. The world&rsquo;s best rated aquarium is named as Monterey Bay Aquarium in California.</p> <p>Travellers&rsquo; Choice awards honour top travel spots worldwide based on the millions of valuable reviews and opinions from TripAdvisor travellers. Award winners were determined using an algorithm that took into account the quantity and quality of reviews for zoos and aquariums worldwide, gathered over a 12-month period.</p> <p>For the complete list of winners from the 2014 Travellers&rsquo; Choice Zoos and Aquariums, as well as reviews and candid traveller photos, go to: </p> <p><a href="http://www.tripadvisor.co.uk/TravellersChoice-Attractions-cZoos">http://www.tripadvisor.co.uk/TravellersChoice-Attractions-cZoos</a></p> <p> </p> <p><a href="http://www.tripadvisor.co.uk/TravellersChoice-Attractions-cAquariums">http://www.tripadvisor.co.uk/TravellersChoice-Attractions-cAquariums</a> </p> <p><strong><br /> </strong></p> <p><strong>Notes to editors</strong></p> <p>Full quote from Chester Zoo: Jamie Christon, managing director of Chester Zoo said, &ldquo;We&rsquo;re absolutely delighted to have received the seal of approval from the public&nbsp; and named the best zoo in the UK and indeed one of the very best in the world.&nbsp;</p> <p>&ldquo;Our sincere thanks go to every single person that has come here because, as a registered charity, their visits help us to carry out all of our vital conservation work &ndash; saving species from extinction both here in the UK and overseas.&rdquo;</p> <p>&ldquo;We&rsquo;re always evolving and offering visitors new, bigger and better experiences. Every year we look to do something new and give people the very best day out.&nbsp;</p> <p><br /> </p></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:03 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{4EB93F05-3199-4146-AFEA-AABD096B1998}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/rock-hyrax-born</link><title>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdLittle brothers of the elephant\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd born at Chester Zoo</title><description><p>Four baby rock hyraxes which have been born at Chester Zoo may look like Guinea pigs \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd but in fact they are one of the closest living relatives of the elephant. </p><figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Rock Hyrax at Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/elephants/rock-hyrax/RockHyrax-4.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p>The tiny youngsters weighed just a few ounces when they arrived on July 20.</p> <p>But despite their slight appearance, the species has a remarkable genetic link to the elephant.</p> <p>Curator of mammals, Tim Rowlands, said:</p> <blockquote> <p>Rock hyraxes and elephants share several common features. They have similar toes, teeth and skull structures and rock hyraxes also have two large continually growing incisors, which correspond to an elephant&rsquo;s tusks.</p> <p>And whereas small mammals normally have a short pregnancy period, for the rock hyrax it lasts for around seven and a half months (245 days) - another sign of their relation to their much larger ancestors.</p> </blockquote> <p>Rock hyraxes are native to Africa but can also be found along the coast of the Arabian Peninsula and in Israel where they are protected by law. As their name suggests, they live in rocky terrain, seeking shelter and protection in rugged outcrops or cliffs.</p> <p>The new arrivals can be seen with their parents in their exhibit at the zoo, which is part of its African painted dogs&rsquo;
