trail.</p> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Rock hyrax at Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/elephants/rock-hyrax/RockHyrax-7.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <h2>Rock hyrax facts</h2> <ul>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Chester Zoo&rsquo;s rock hyrax mum is five-years-old, born on 8/7/2009</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Dad, </span><em style="line-height: 1.3;">Nungu</em><span style="line-height: 1.3;">, is four years and 11 months old, born on 18/8/2009</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Hyraxes don&rsquo;t need much water because they get most of it from their food</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Hyrax feet are built for rock climbing - the bottom of each foot is bare and has a moist, rubbery pad that provides a suction-cup effect to help the hyrax cling to rocks without slipping</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Rock hyraxes have excellent eye sight</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">When the pups are born they look like miniature adults &ndash; born with their eyes and ears open and with the same coat</span></li> </ul></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:03 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{7512859A-631F-4366-AB18-E38CCE61F3DF}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/rare-parrot-given-endangered-status</link><title>Rare parrot given \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdendangered\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd status in new report following zoo team\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds study</title><description><p>A rare parrot has been given a new \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdendangered\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd status after a group of researchers from Chester Zoo headed to South America to track down and learn more about the species.</p><figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Chester" src="/~/media/news/2014/Ecuador-22.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <figcaption>Chester Zoo sent an expedition to South America to search for a rare parrot known as the Ecuador Amazon</figcaption> </figure> <p>The zoo&rsquo;s team of 10, which included experienced conservationists, biologists, avian and horticultural experts, spent two weeks following the Ecuador Amazon parrot &ndash; a bird that was only recognised as a species in its own right in December 2013 after years of study by the zoo&rsquo;s director general, Dr Mark Pilgrim.</p> <p>Previously, the Ecuador Amazon parrot was considered to be a subspecies of a common group of birds, with a population of about five million. As a result of the size of the population, it did not rank among conservationists&rsquo; priorities.</p> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Dr Mark Pilgrim" src="/~/media/news/2014/Dr Mark Pilgrim spent years studying the parrots.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <figcaption>Dr Mark Pilgrim spent years studying the parrots</figcaption> </figure> <p>However with full species status awarded the parrot has now taken on a whole new level of importance. Only 600 individuals are estimated to be left, prompting the species to be officially listed as endangered and put at a very high risk of extinction in the wild.</p> <p>The listing was made for the first time by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature&rsquo;s (IUCN) Red List of Threatened Species, which evaluates the conservation status of plant and animals species.&nbsp;</p> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Ecuador amazon parrot" src="/~/media/news/2014/Ecuador amazon parrot.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <figcaption>Ecuador amazon parrot</figcaption> </figure> <p>Dr Pilgrim said:</p> <blockquote> <p>The estimated total population for this species is about 600. But the sub-populations are less than 250 birds. So, based on our findings, the IUCN is now classifying the birds as an endangered species.</p> <p>This new listing is something of a double-edged sword. While on the one hand it confirms that the species&rsquo; continued existence is under real threat, the good news is that it will now be considered a conservation priority and will attract resources.</p> </blockquote> <p>The expedition team was based in the Cerro Blanco forest in South West Ecuador where they gathered new information on the parrots&rsquo; behaviour and feeding habits and conducted a survey on the two unique types of habitat that they rely on &ndash; mangroves and dry forest.</p> <blockquote> <p>Very little was known about the Ecuador Amazon parrot in the wild, added Dr Pilgrim. That&rsquo;s precisely why the team and I spent a number of weeks trekking in the oppressive humidity of the forest - one of the few remaining remnants of tropical dry forest in the world &ndash; to gather new data about the species.</p> <p>If truth be told though we actually came back with far more questions than answers. Suddenly, there are a number of things that we didn't expect and we now have questions about &ndash; but that&rsquo;s science.</p> </blockquote> <p>One example was how the parrots chose their roosting sites within the mangroves of Puerto Hondo, located along the western coast of Ecuador.</p> <blockquote> <p>We knew from past literature and from a previous visit we had made that the parrots roost in the mangroves and fly to the dry forests to feed. The assumption was that they did that to protect themselves from predators that were not found on the mangrove islands.</p> <p>However, the birds fly very, very far out into the mangroves &ndash; why do they need to do that? Nearby shrimp farms use bird scaring devices, which are designed to frighten herons and shore birds and stop them eating the farms' stock. So is this affecting the parrots' behaviour? We just don't know.</p> </blockquote> <p>Something Dr Pilgrim could say for certain though was that there are some very positive signs as far as the remaining habitat is concerned.</p> <blockquote> <p>From our survey of 30km of forest trails and from images we managed to obtain via our camera traps, we saw there is a wide amount of biodiversity within the Cerro Blanco Forest, illustrating a healthy ecosystem.</p> <p>We saw no evidence of illegal activity and areas that just 20 years ago used to be farm land are now on their way to be restored to their former glory. This is excellent news &ndash; a credit to the work that the Pro Bosque Foundation [a local conservation organisation working to protect the forest] puts in and a real basis for hope in terms of preserving not only the parrots but all of the other wonderful wildlife that calls the forest its home as well. In that sense, it is very reassuring that the area appears to be well protected.&nbsp;</p> </blockquote> <p>The zoo now hopes to repeat the Cerro Blanco survey every three years in order to build up a long-term dataset that would allow researchers to monitor the parrots' population dynamics.</p> <p>Dr Pilgrim added:</p> <blockquote> <p>While there is concern, there is still a lot to do before we can make clear and bold statements about exactly what is happening to this fantastic species. </p> </blockquote></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:03 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{AF5CD6E2-063F-4CFE-895A-CF9B478B5E99}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/giant-python-given-ultrasound</link><title>Giant python JF given ultrasound heart scan at Chester Zoo</title><description><p>While we all tend to dread visits to the doctor \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd not many of us require ten people to get us there.</p><figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Python health check" src="/~/media/news/2014/python/Python-17.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p>But Chester Zoo&rsquo;s JF the python is no ordinary patient, and as she measures around 23ft in length, the great snake required a team of zookeepers and vets to carry her in for her annual health check.</p> <p>The reticulated python &ndash; the longest species of snake in the world &ndash; had her eyes covered to keep her calm as she was looked over. Indeed JF is thought to be one of the biggest snakes in Europe, weighing in at around 60kgs.&nbsp;</p> <p>As well as checks on her general health, JF met cardio experts &ndash; Eric Stohr and Aimee Drane from Cardiff Metropolitan University &ndash; who took the opportunity to perform an ultrasound scan on the giant snake&rsquo;s heart.&nbsp;</p>  <div class="video">   <iframe frameborder="0" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/Cljbbz4bgLI?rel=0"> </iframe> <div class="video-mask video-mask__top"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__right"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__bottom"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__left"></div> </div> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Python ultrasound - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/python/Python-19.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Python ultrasound at Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/python/Python-20.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p>The zoo's pythons are taking part in cardiological study as part of a joint research programme between the zoo and the university. It is hoped that looking at JF will also provide insight for people studying the human heart.&nbsp;</p> <p>The team of cardio experts have attempted similar tests on giraffes and sharks but say snake hearts are of particular interest because they have three chambers, unlike human hearts which have four.</p> <p>Steve Unwin, from Chester Zoo&rsquo;s vet team, said:</p> <blockquote> <p>We&rsquo;re pleased that we&rsquo;ve been able to get some nice, clear ultrasound images of JF&rsquo;s heart and it&rsquo;s helped us to see that she&rsquo;s healthy on the inside, as well as on the outside. That&rsquo;s the primary reason we wanted to have a good look at JF today &ndash; to ensure she&rsquo;s in tip top condition.&nbsp;</p> <p>But, adding to this, we&rsquo;re also interested in anything that can help with the understanding of human heart health. It is already proven that a snake&rsquo;s heart can expand and reduce in size in relation to eating a big meal and digesting it. But the only time the heart thickens or thins in humans is when there are real cardio problems. So if we can build up our knowledge of how snake hearts function, we could potentially learn a lot from this comparative data.</p> </blockquote> <p>Reticulated pythons are native to south east Asia, a region in which Chester Zoo is involved in several conservation projects looking to protect animal and plant species in the wild.</p> <p>The species&rsquo; large size and distinctive scale patterns have resulted in them being heavily exploited for skin to make popular leather products such as belts, wallets and boots. Habitat loss is another significant threat.</p> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Reticulated python health check" src="/~/media/news/2014/python/Python-38.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <h2>About reticulated pythons</h2> <ul>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">The world&rsquo;s longest species of snake</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">They are native to southeast Asia, a region in which Chester Zoo is involved in several key conservation projects looking to save animal and plant species from extinction</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Live in forests woodlands, grasslands and often near waterways</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">At Chester Zoo the pythons are fed every six to eight weeks - a diet of whole turkeys, chickens or rabbits</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">They have sharp teeth which they use to hold their prey before crushing and suffocating them with their body</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Female reticulated pythons are capable of laying between 60 and 100 eggs at a time, which take between 70-90 days to hatch</span></li> </ul> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Python healthcheck at Chester ZOo" src="/~/media/news/2014/python/Python-13.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:03 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{2A7DC06F-4AE3-413B-BDD1-AC67238B5534}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/smallest-baby-deer-born</link><title>Smallest baby deer born at Chester Zoo</title><description><p>Chester Zoo has welcomed a rare pudu fawn - the world\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds smallest species of deer.</p><figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Pudu - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/hoofed-animals/pudu/Pudu-4 (2).ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <figcaption>A rare pudu &ndash; the world&rsquo;s smallest species of deer &ndash; has been born at Chester Zoo</figcaption></figure> <p>The baby pudu, which keepers have named Selene, is part of a European conservation breeding programme to protect the species.</p> <p>Native to the temperate rainforests of Chile and south-west Argentina, the pudu is classed by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) as vulnerable to extinction in the wild.&nbsp;</p> <p>Curator of mammals Tim Rowlands said:</p> <blockquote> <p>Pudu numbers have declined partly due to their habitat being destroyed and cleared for cattle ranching and other human developments, as well as persecution from domestic and hunting dogs.</p> <p>So they may be the world&rsquo;s smallest deer but, to us, the birth of our new charge is a very big achievement.&nbsp;</p> </blockquote> <p>The youngster was born to mum Serena and dad Odin.&nbsp;</p> <h2>Pudu facts</h2> <ul>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;"> A fully grown pudu stands at 38cm (15in at the shoulder) and weighs about 9-15kg (20-33lbs)</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;"> A male&rsquo;s antlers only grow to four inches long</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;"> A single youngster is born after a gestation of 210 days</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;"> The zoo&rsquo;s new youngster &ndash;  a female, named Selene by zookeepers - was born on 22/05/2014</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;"> Young pudu are born with distinctive white spotted markings on their backs to help camouflage them from predators, which include pumas and foxes</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;"> Pudu feed on new leaves and shoots of trees</span></li> </ul> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="pudu zoo" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/hoofed-animals/pudu/Pudu-3 (2).ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:03 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{7BF80ABC-A523-4AB5-8E24-243B2F6AE20E}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/unusual-new-arrival</link><title>Unusual new arrival will be a real pretty Polly</title><description><p>A rare parrot is receiving some special attention at Chester Zoo. </p><figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Hyacinth macaw - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/macaw/Macaw-1.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <figcaption>Is it a dinosaur? Is it a plucked chicken? No, it&rsquo;s a parrot! Keepers at Chester Zoo are providing around-the-clock care to a rare hyacinth macaw chick named Jessie. The baby bird, who is now a month old, is being fed up to nine times a day in a Tupperware tub which is acting as a crib. The species is endangered in the wild as wild populations have undergone rapid reductions in recent years due to the illegal pet trade and habitat loss. </figcaption></figure> <p>The month-old hyacinth macaw chick is being hand-reared by zookeepers after it was hatched in an incubator.</p> <p>The chick, which is described as looking like a &ldquo;cross between a dinosaur and a plucked chicken&rdquo;, is so small that it is being kept in a Tupperware tub that is doubling up as a crib.</p> <p>Keepers, who are providing the baby bird with around-the-clock care, have given the youngster the unisex name Jessie &ndash; as it will be some time until it develops feathers that they can send away for DNA analysis in order to sex the youngster.&nbsp;</p> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Hyacinth macaw - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/macaw/Macaw-21.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p>Keeper Karen Neech said:</p> <blockquote> <p>&ldquo;It&rsquo;s hard to believe that our chick will eventually start to spring some beautiful deep blue feathers &ndash; at the moment it looks more like a dinosaur crossed with a plucked chicken!&nbsp;</p> <p>&ldquo;But with all of the care and attention we&rsquo;re giving, it&rsquo;s growing bigger and stronger by the day. At the moment I&rsquo;m feeding it a special mixture of powdered vitamins every two hours between 6am until 11pm. This will go on for around three months until the bird is weaned and can feed by itself.</p> <p>&ldquo;At this stage our new charge is doing really well &ndash; we&rsquo;re really pleased.&rdquo;&nbsp;</p> </blockquote> <p>Hyacinth macaws are the world&rsquo;s largest parrot and are found in Brazil, Bolivia and Paraguay. They are considered an endangered species as wild populations have undergone rapid reductions in recent years due to the illegal pet trade and habitat loss as a result of land clearance for cattle ranching.</p> <p>The striking birds also have a naturally slow reproductive rate, which means that once a population is reduced through over trapping and habitat loss, it takes a long time to recover.</p> <p>Karen added:</p> <blockquote> <p>&ldquo;The hatching of this chick is a major step forward in our efforts to ensure a healthy insurance population of these stunning birds exists in zoos.</p> <p>&ldquo;On top of that, the skills that the bird keeping team develop whilst hand-rearing the chick at the zoo can be applied to our conservation programmes in the wild - something we&rsquo;ve been able to do successfully with species such as the endangered echo parakeet in Mauritius.&rdquo;&nbsp;</p> </blockquote> <p>Jesse&rsquo;s parents, who can be seen in the zoo&rsquo;s Tropical Realm, are affectionately known as James Bond and Miss Moneypenny. Dad gets his name from his ring number &ndash; 007. </p> <p><br /> </p> <h2>Hyacinth macaw facts&nbsp;</h2> <ul>     <li> Hyacinth macaws are the biggest birds in the parrot family, reaching up to 100cm tall</li>     <li> In the wild they live in north and central Brazil, north west Paraguay and eastern Bolivia</li>     <li> Adults have deep blue feathers, a yellow ring around their eye and yellow near their black, curved beaks</li>     <li> Most of their feeding is done on the ground where they use their bumper sized beaks to crack large palm nuts that are much too tough for any other animal to break open. They have a bone inside their tongue which makes it an excellent tool for breaking open and eating food</li>     <li> In the wild they live in South America, mainly Brazil, but numbers have fallen drastically</li>     <li> Over recent decades they were relentlessly hunted for the pet trade and also suffered as farms and urban developers took over large parts of the forests where they live</li>     <li> The availability of the palm tree species from which they get the nuts to feed on is crucial for their continued survival. Pairs mostly nest in tree hollows, but sometimes in holes or caves</li>     <li> Females usually lay two white eggs, which they sit on for 30 days, then chicks stay in the nest, getting stronger, for another 100 days.</li>     <li> They are part of a European endangered species breeding programme, a carefully managed scheme overseeing the breeding of the birds in different countries&nbsp;</li>     <li> By visiting the zoo, visitors help to continue valuable breeding programmes and research into the world&rsquo;s rare and exotic bird species&nbsp;</li>     <li> Parents James Bond and Miss Moneypenny arrived at Chester from USA in 1992</li>     <li> The chick hatched on 15/06/2014</li> </ul> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Hyacinth macaw at Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/macaw/Macaw-18.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:03 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{1B79F24E-9FD3-464E-9EE0-D075CD330C2B}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/gentle-lemur-born</link><title>Wide-eyed newborn gentle lemur makes debut at Chester Zoo </title><description><p>An endangered species of lemur has become the first of its kind to be born at Chester Zoo.</p><figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Gentle Lemur at Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/monkeys-and-apes/lemur/gentle-lemur/GentleLemur-1.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <figcaption> An as yet unnamed gentle lemur, pictured with mum Molly, is the first of its kind to ever be born at Chester Zoo.</figcaption></figure> <p>The new youngster &ndash; an Alaotran gentle lemur - arrived to mum Molly and dad Fady.&nbsp;</p> <p>Keepers have kept a close eye on the new family during the baby&rsquo;s important first few weeks, although staff are still uncertain about the one-month-old&rsquo;s sex.&nbsp;</p> <p>Curator of mammals, Tim Rowlands, said:</p> <blockquote> <p>&ldquo;Both mum and dad are doing a great job of bringing up their new charge. Mum is super protective and dad is also pulling his weight &ndash; he occasionally helps to do some of the carrying.</p> <p>&ldquo;This is a critically endangered species. They face a very real threat of extinction in the wild and this is the first time the species has ever bred at Chester Zoo.&rdquo;</p> </blockquote> <p>In the wild the Alaotran gentle lemur is only found around Lake Alaotra in Madagascar. The species is being threatened by habitat destruction as the reed beds where it lives are being burned and the lake drained for rice irrigation.&nbsp;</p> <p>They are also caught for food and others are captured and sold as pets who rarely survive, meaning they are classed as critically endangered by the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN). It is believed that just 2,500 remain in the wild.&nbsp;</p> <h2>Gentle lemur facts&nbsp;</h2> <ul>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;"> Species: Alaotran gentle lemur</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;"> Wild Alaotran gentle lemurs are only found inhabiting the reed beds around Lake Alaotra in Madagascar</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;"> They are classed as critically endangered by the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN)</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;"> The species is being threatened by habitat destruction as the reed beds where it lives are being burned and the lake drained for rice irrigation</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;"> Just 2,500 are thought to remain in the wild</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;"> Mum: Molly, five-years-old, born 28/03/2009</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;"> Dad: Fady, three-years-old, born 13/11/2010</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;"> Baby: Born 06/06/2014</span></li> </ul></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:03 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{05237EE8-C5FB-4D1B-B3B6-AA62D56E975E}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/rare-banteng-calf-born</link><title>Rare banteng calf born at Chester Zoo</title><description><p>A rare banteng has been born at Chester Zoo.</p><figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Banteng - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/hoofed-animals/banteng/image002.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <figcaption>Ear, ear! A rare banteng &ndash; a species of wild cattle from south east Asia - has been born at Chester Zoo. It is estimated that between 5,000 and 8,000 individuals are left in the wild, largely due to the loss of their forest habitat and hunting.</figcaption></figure> <p>The male calf &ndash; who is yet to be named &ndash; arrived to mum Pankhuri and dad Gaston.</p> <p>Also known as tembadau, the banteng is a species of wild cattle native to the forests of south east Asia. </p> <p>Banteng are listed as endangered by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) who say the species has declined by 95 percent since the 1960s. Hunting for the trade in their horns, meat and traditional medicines and the accelerated loss of their forest habitat are just two factors which have reduced their numbers to an estimated 5,000 - 8,000 in the wild. </p> <p>Curator of mammals Tim Rowlands said:</p> <blockquote> <p>&ldquo;South east Asia is home to some of the most threatened species on the planet and it&rsquo;s frightening to think that on a busy summer day, more people will visit Chester Zoo than there are banteng left in the wild.</p> <p>&ldquo;Hopefully our new young boy &ndash; who is doing very well indeed &ndash; will inspire a few more people to take notice of this very special species. Better still we hope he&rsquo;ll connect them with the plight of his cousins in the wild. The name &lsquo;wild cattle&rsquo; maybe doesn&rsquo;t conjure up images of a species under threat but with only a few thousand left, there&rsquo;s no doubt that this magnificent animal faces an uncertain future.&rdquo;</p> </blockquote> <p>The new youngster is the third calf to be born in Chester following Penni and Gus who both arrived in May 2013. The zoo now has a herd of six &ndash; three males and three females.</p> <p>In spring 2015 the herd will move into a whole new area of the zoo when we open our <a href="/islands/islands-news">Islands project</a>. As a visitor to Islands you will go on an expedition &ndash; moving through detailed recreations of habitats in the Philippines, Bali, Sulawesi, Papua, Sumba and Sumatra. </p> <p>We hope that the development, the biggest and most ambitions in UK zoo history, will showcase its conservation work in south east Asia and highlight the threats faced by species such as Sumatran orangutan, Sumatran tigers, Visayan warty pigs and Bali starlings as well as banteng. </p> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"><img alt="Banteng - Chester ZOo" src="/~/media/pr-folder/Banteng18 Custom.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p>&nbsp;</p> <h2>Banteng facts</h2> <ul>     <li>The zoo&rsquo;s new youngster was born on May 9</li>     <li>In the wild, the once-thriving species has been reduced to small, isolated populations whose numbers are in decline and are at risk from a host of threats including poaching inside protected areas, habitat loss, hybridisation with domestic cattle and infections from domestic cattle diseases</li>     <li>Banteng play a key role in circulating nutrients through ecosystems, dispersing seeds and maintaining food chains. They are and are a critical food source for many carnivore species, including tigers and leopards</li>     <li>On June 4 2014, Fauna and Flora International (FFI) announced the discovery of a new population of banteng (Bos javanicus) in north-western Cambodia. Camera trap images of six banteng were taken in a 9,500-hectare community forest in Siem Reap Province, where the species was previously believed to have gone extinct</li> </ul> <p>&nbsp;</p></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:03 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{C69826EC-E12A-4720-9C67-7D28583E4845}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/even-more-baby-warthogs</link><title>Hogging the limelight! Two warthog litters arrive just weeks apart at Chester Zoo </title><description><p>What\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds that thing about buses? You wait an age for the first one to turn up and then as if by magic another arrives in quick succession.</p><p>At Chester Zoo, it&rsquo;s not so much buses but warthog piglets!</p> <p>A second litter has been born at the zoo - just weeks after its first ever piglets arrived last month.&nbsp;</p> <p>The latest tiny trio, who stand at just 30cm tall, have been born to mum Kizzy. They come hot on the heels (or should that be trotters) of two more who are the offspring of mum Tamzin.&nbsp;</p> <div class="video">   <iframe frameborder="0" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/ym2Kp0-cQsY?rel=0"></iframe> <div class="video-mask video-mask__top"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__right"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__bottom"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__left"></div> </div> <p>Keepers don&rsquo;t yet know how many of the new arrivals are boys and how many are girls and so, for the time being, all of the newcomers remain nameless.&nbsp;</p> <p>Curator of mammals, Tim Rowlands, said:</p> <blockquote> <p>&ldquo;We waited quite some time for our first warthog family and then wouldn&rsquo;t you know it, both of our females give birth within a matter of weeks!</p> <p>&ldquo;We&rsquo;re delighted with our quintet. When five playful warthog piglets get together they can create a lot of mischief &ndash; so I&rsquo;m sure they&rsquo;ll soon hog lots of attention over the coming months.&rdquo;&nbsp;</p> </blockquote> <p>Conservation charity Chester Zoo is part of a European breeding programme for the species, which arrived in Cheshire 10 years ago.&nbsp;</p> <p>Warthogs are wild pigs native to Africa and known for their large upward curving tusks and wart-like growths on the sides of their heads. They live up to 15 years and can grow as large as 113kg.</p> <p><br /> </p> <h2>Warthog facts&nbsp;</h2> <ul>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Warthogs have one or two pairs of warts on their face beneath the eyes and near the tusks</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Males are larger than females but both sexes have upper and lower tusks</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">They feed mainly on grass, roots, bark, fruit and berries but will sometimes eat insects, worms and dead animals</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Warthogs are found in sub-Saharan Africa</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">They are active in the day and hide away at night, most often in burrows that have been made by aardvarks</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Mother warthogs nurse and care for their offspring until they are about 21 weeks of age, at which point they have to fend for themselves</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Chester Zoo&rsquo;s first youngsters were born on 2/5/2014. The second litter arrived on 6/6/2014</span></li>     <li><span style="line-height: 1.3;">They can be seen in the zoo&rsquo;s Tsavo exhibit, near its Diamond Jubilee Quarter&nbsp;</span></li> </ul></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:03 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{63086B48-5143-4CCE-9597-EE55363AA885}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/large-heath-butterfly</link><title>Rare butterfly returns to the wild </title><description><p>A butterfly missing from a Lancashire nature reserve for more than 100 years is making a comeback.</p><figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Large heath butterfly" src="/~/media/news/2014/large-heath-butterfly600px.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <p>The rare species &ndash; known as the large heath butterfly - is being reintroduced to Heysham Moss thanks to a project involving Chester Zoo, Lancashire Wildlife Trust and funder Lancashire Environmental Fund.</p> <p>Large heath butterflies were last recorded at the site at the beginning of the 20th century. However a new breeding programme, which began last year when a small number of adult females from a donor site at Winmarleigh where a healthy population of the butterflies still exist, were taken to the zoo. And under the guidance of the zoo&rsquo;s experts, the butterflies were bred under controlled conditions and are now being released as adult butterflies onto Heysham Moss.</p> <div class="video">   <iframe frameborder="0" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/xWZu0kPcgvs?rel=0"> </iframe> <div class="video-mask video-mask__top"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__right"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__bottom"></div> <div class="video-mask video-mask__left"></div> </div> <p>The zoo&rsquo;s biodiversity officer Sarah Bird said:</p> <blockquote> <p>&ldquo;We&rsquo;re excited to be able to support this project financially and particularly thrilled to be able to use zoo expertise and facilities to help restore large heath butterflies to Heysham Moss.</p> <p>&ldquo;It has been fascinating to follow the life cycle of this rare butterfly at the zoo and we&rsquo;re extremely pleased that the pupae we have so carefully reared are now hatching at Heysham Moss, their new home.&rdquo;</p> </blockquote> <p>The Wildlife Trust&rsquo;s North Lancashire Reserves manager Reuben Neville added:</p> <blockquote> <p>&ldquo;After a year of anticipation and the first phase of the project now completed, seeing the first large heath butterflies flying again on our reserve has been incredibly exciting and a credit to the zoo staff who have nurtured them over the past year.</p> <p>&ldquo;The large heath butterfly was formerly much more widespread in North West England, inhabiting lowland raised bog and occasionally blanket bog habitats. Now extinct in Cheshire, Greater Manchester and Merseyside, it hangs on in just two widely separated sites in Lancashire.</p> <p>&ldquo;Now with funding from the Lancashire Environmental Fund and project partners Chester Zoo it is hoped to re-establish a sustainable population at Heysham.&rdquo;</p> </blockquote> <p>Since the Wildlife Trust purchased Heysham Moss in 2004 extensive habitat management work has been undertaken and it is now considered sufficient to support a population of large heath butterflies. </p> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Large heath butterfly" src="/~/media/news/2014/Large heath butterflies are carried to the Heysham Moss reserve in Lancashire where they are being released.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:03 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{28E26328-B99C-486E-9376-9183E6BFBACE}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/best-animal-attraction</link><title>Chester Zoo voted UK\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds best animal attraction</title><description><p>We've been voted the UK\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds best animal attraction.</p><figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Spectacled bear" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/bears/Bernie1 Custom.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <figcaption>Chester Zoo has been voted the UK&rsquo;s best animal attraction at the prestigious Group Travel Awards. New arrivals, such a Bernardo the spectacled bear, continue to see the zoo evolve and offer visitors new experiences.</figcaption></figure> <p>The zoo scooped the accolade at the prestigious 2014 Group Travel Awards at a ceremony held in London &ndash; beating off competition from the likes of Yorkshire Wildlife Park, London Zoo, National SEA LIFE Centre and West Midlands Safari Park. </p> <p>Chester Zoo&rsquo;s marketing officer Julie Griffin said:</p> <blockquote> <p>&ldquo;This is the first time we&rsquo;ve won this award and we&rsquo;re very, very pleased indeed &ndash; particularly as it&rsquo;s voted for by those working in the travel industry who have been to the zoo, experienced what we have to offer and cast their vote on the back of their visit.</p> <p>&ldquo;The zoo is constantly evolving and offering visitors something different to see and experience &ndash; whether that&rsquo;s a new  animal, such as spectacled bear Bernardo who has just arrived from America, or the opening of a new venture such as our ice-cream parlour. Looking ahead, we&rsquo;ll be opening our major new attraction Islands which will take visitors on their very own conservation expedition when it launches in spring next year.&rdquo; </p> </blockquote> <p>Islands - the biggest and most ambitious development in UK zoo history &ndash; will open at the zoo in spring 2015. The &pound;30m project will see visitors set off on an expedition - moving through detailed recreations of habitats in the Philippines, Bali, Sulawesi, Papua, Sumba and Sumatra. They will walk over bridges, travel in boats and see buildings that are architecturally identical to those found in south east Asia.</p> <p>Visitors can expect to see species such as warty pigs, banteng cattle, cassowaries, Sumatran tigers, Sulawesi macaques, Sumatran orangutans and sunda gharial crocodiles along the way. </p> <p>Mrs Griffin added:</p> <blockquote> <p>&ldquo;Islands is all about immersion &ndash; we&rsquo;re looking to take our visitors on an adventure where, for a couple of hours, they feel like they&rsquo;re in south east Asia. There&rsquo;s nothing else like it in the UK.&rdquo;</p> </blockquote> <p>Groups, tour operators, coach companies and travel agents will be able to ensure their parties are amongst the first to experience Islands with bookings being taken from June 2014, with special advanced rates available for groups who book before December this year.</p> <p>The Group Travel Awards are voted for by readers of Group Travel Organiser magazine.  It recognises all the very best suppliers to the group travel industry from hotels and resorts to airlines and cruise lines. </p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <h2>Group admissions</h2> <p>&bull; Bookings can be made by calling the events and sales team on 0870 720 1507 or email <a href="mailto:groups@chesterzoo.org">groups@chesterzoo.org</a><br /> &bull; Familiarisation trips are available for group party organisers. For details contact Julie Griffin - <a href="mailto:j.griffin@chesterzoo.org">j.griffin@chesterzoo.org<br /> </a>&bull; Free coach parking and coach driver admission. Coach parking is available at the Diamond Jubilee Quarter</p> <p>2015 admission ticket &ndash; advance trade exclusive (for bookings made before 31 December 2014)</p> <p>One ticket covers both the zoo and Islands.<br /> <br /> <em>Group rate for 15 or more:</em></p> <p>&bull; Adult: &pound;17.50<br /> &bull; Children (3-15 years): &pound;14.50<br /> &bull; Infant (aged 2 and under): Free<br /> &bull; Full time students and 65+: &pound;16<br /> &bull; Carer (accompanying a disabled guest): Free</p></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:03 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{0195983B-7428-47B2-BDB8-862CF27202F7}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/spectacled-bear-arrives</link><title>Quite the spectacle! Bernardo the male spectacled bear arrives in new Chester Zoo breeding plan</title><description><p>A young male bear has arrived at Chester Zoo from the USA to be part of the zoo\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds future plans to breed the animals.</p><figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Spectacled bear" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/bears/spectacled-bear-600-px.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> <figcaption>Four-year-old spectacled bear Bernardo relaxes his new enclosure at Chester Zoo after arriving from Tulsa Zoo in Oklahoma.</figcaption></figure> <p><span style="line-height: 1.3;">Four-year-old Bernardo &ndash; a spectacled bear &ndash; has moved in to the Cheshire zoo after travelling from Tulsa Zoo in Oklahoma. He is slowly being introduced to his new companion, Chester&rsquo;s resident female Franka.</span></p> <p>It is rare that any zoo animals move between Europe and the USA. However, Bernardo&rsquo;s arrival brings important new blood to the European population of spectacled bears &ndash; a species classed by the International Union of Conservation of Nature (IUCN) as being vulnerable to extinction in the wild. Tim Rowlands, the zoo&rsquo;s curator of mammals said:</p> <blockquote> <p>&ldquo;An exchange of animals between the USA and Europe doesn&rsquo;t happen very often at all. That makes the arrival of Bernardo even more special.</p> <p>&ldquo;The co-ordinator of this breeding programme chose him as an ideal genetic pairing for our female Franka and so that has been the driver for bringing him across the Atlantic. Spectacled bears are a species that is vulnerable to extinction and so we hope this pair will produce cubs in the future. </p> <p>&ldquo;Bringing an animal over from the USA is logistically very difficult and it&rsquo;s vitally important that the animal has a suitable temperament. I went over to Tulsa last year to see Bernardo and spend some time with him and he&rsquo;s a very nice, calm young male.</p> <p>&ldquo;We also have one of the largest spectacled bear enclosures in the world and so we were top of the list when it came to choosing Bernardo&rsquo;s new home.&rdquo; </p> </blockquote> <p>To ensure Bernardo was made as comfortable as possible during the 4,300 mile journey, a specially designed, purpose-built crate was made in Deeside in north Wales before being flown over to Tulsa. </p> <p>Mr Rowlands added:</p> <blockquote> <p>&ldquo;Bernardo arrived safely and is spending time exploring his new home. Both he and Franka are finding ways of getting to know each other &ndash; and that may involve a little bit of rough and tumble - but they&rsquo;ll soon settle down. </p> <p>&ldquo;Spectacled bears are by and large a mysterious species and not a great deal is known about them. But by working closely with him here, we hope our keepers will learn new things and be able to relay that information to our conservation partners in the wild - information that could be very useful indeed in terms of ensuring the bears&rsquo; long-term survival.&rdquo;</p> </blockquote> <p>Last year the zoo funded a project in Peru investigating the foraging behaviour of spectacled bears. The project ultimately aims to ensure the conservation of the species in the dry forest habitat of northern Peru through scientific research and education, while working collaboratively with private land owners and rural communities to improve their social and economic wellbeing.</p> <h2>More pics</h2> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Spectacled bear" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/bears/Bernie-33.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Spectacled bear at Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/bears/Bernie-11.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure> <figure> <div class="figure-image-wrapper"> <img alt="Spectacled bears" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/bears/Bernie-38.ashx" /> <div class="figure-image-mask"></div> </div> </figure></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:03 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{BB68E817-021A-43D2-9D1F-246C33BEB375}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/rooney-the-penguin-chick</link><title>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdRooney\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd the penguin chick begins training as keepers kick off their 2014 penguin cr\ufffd\ufffdche at Chester Zoo</title><description><p><img src="/~/media/news/2014/rooney/Rooney the penguin chick at Chester Zoo (6).ashx" alt="Rooney the penguin chick at Chester Zoo " /></p> <p style="font-size: 11px; text-align: center;"><strong>Eight-week-old penguin chick Rooney is held aloft by keeper Karen Neech at Chester Zoo. Rooney is one of five chicks to be named after England World Cup stars &ndash; along with Gerrard, Banks, Moore and Hurst. The tiny team will be taught how to swim, hunt and feed in water in a special nursery pool at the zoo.<br /> </strong></p> <p class="intro-first">As a certain Wayne Rooney prepares to kick off England&rsquo;s World Cup campaign in Brazil, his feathered namesake at Chester Zoo has joined the penguin class of 2014 and started cr&egrave;che. </p> <p>Each year keepers at the zoo name their new charges after a particular theme. In 2013 their clutch got their names from characters from the hit TV show Dr Who and this time around they&rsquo;ve been named after English World Cup stars past and present.</p> <p>Rooney the penguin, who hatched in spring, has moved into a nursery at the zoo to learn some penguin basics &ndash; along with classmates Gerrard, Banks and Moore. </p> <p>And just as school children have to learn their ABCs, the zoo&rsquo;s youngsters will be taught how to swim, hunt and feed in water.</p> <p><img src="/~/media/news/2014/rooney/World Cup penguin chicks at Chester Zoo pose for the cameras.ashx" alt="World Cup penguin chicks at Chester Zoo pose for the cameras" /></p> <p>Penguin team manager Andy Woolham said:</p> <p>&ldquo;For our penguin chicks this is a learning process of two halves. We kick off their education with lessons in and around our shallow nursery pool where the main goal is to build up their confidence. Then, when we&rsquo;re happy they can take fish from our keepers and no longer need to rely on regurgitated food from mum and dad, they graduate to our main pool. Here they continue the learning process by following the lead of the adults in the colony.&rdquo; </p> <p>The penguins are an endangered South American species, which come from the coastal areas of Peru and Chile. The new arrivals mean the zoo now has a colony of 42.</p> <p><img src="/~/media/news/2014/rooney/Banks the penguin chick at Chester Zoo.ashx" alt="Banks the penguin chick at Chester Zoo" /></p> <p>Mr Woolham added:</p> <p>&ldquo;Rooney is so far showing a great appetite for learning. When the time comes we hope he will dive with great elegance. </p> <p>&ldquo;Gerrard is still with mum at the moment but we&rsquo;re confident he&rsquo;ll soon be showing real promise and could end up top of our mini-league! Hopefully the great form that our penguin chicks are starting to show will be matched by their namesakes out in Brazil.&rdquo; </p> <p>Chester Zoo funds conservation initiatives in the penguins&rsquo; homeland to help them in their natural habitat, where they are faced with many pressures including over fishing of their food and habitat loss. </p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <h2>Humboldt penguin facts</h2> <p>&bull; This South American penguin is named after the chilly Humboldt current, along which it commonly swims<br /> &bull; In the wild, Humboldt penguins are vulnerable to disturbances in their food chain caused by strong El Nino currents<br /> &bull; Humboldt penguins are social animals, living in relatively large colonies of closely spaced burrows<br /> &bull; Humboldt penguins &lsquo;fly&rsquo; through the water at speeds of up to 25mph<br /> &bull; They enjoy a diet of small fish (anchovies, herring, smelt) and crustaceans<br /> &bull; Of the world&rsquo;s 17 penguin species, Humboldts are among the most at risk, with the species classed as vulnerable to extinction by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) <br /> &bull; Rooney&rsquo;s parents are called Kingfisher and Opal (named after birds and sweets)<br /> &bull; Rooney is named after England forward Wayne, Gerrard after England captain Steven, Banks after 1966 World Cup winning goalkeeper Gordon and Moore after 1966 World Cup winning captain Bobby<br /> &nbsp;</p></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:03 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{00BFF60C-436D-4256-9B1C-45C697D9CF7C}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/large-heath-fly-again</link><title>Large Heath fly again at Heysham Moss Nature Reserve</title><description><p>A butterfly missing from a Lancashire nature reserve for more than 100 years has started to make a comeback.</p><p><img alt="Heath butterfly" src="/~/media/news/2014/Butterfly-20.ashx" /></p> <p>Up until the 7th June 2014, the last record of the Large Heath butterfly at Heysham Moss was made at the beginning of the 20th Century.</p> <p>Now a project involving Lancashire Wildlife Trust, Chester Zoo and funder Lancashire Environmental Fund, has begun to introduce the Large Heath butterfly back to the Trust&rsquo;s nature reserve.</p> <p>The Trust&rsquo;s North Lancashire Reserves Manager Reuben Neville said: </p> <p>&ldquo;After a year of anticipation and the first phase of the project now completed, seeing the first Large Heath Butterflies flying again on our reserve has been incredibly exciting and a credit to the Zoo staff who have nurtured them over the past year.&rdquo;</p> <p>&ldquo;The Large heath butterfly was formerly much more widespread in North West England, inhabiting lowland raised bog and occasionally blanket bog habitats.  Now extinct in Cheshire, Greater Manchester and Merseyside, the Large Heath butterfly hangs on in just two widely separated sites in Lancashire.  One is on the Bowland Fells, the other Winmarleigh Moss SSSI. </p> <p>&ldquo;Now with funding from the Lancashire Environmental Fund and project partners Chester Zoo it is hoped to re-establish a sustainable population at Heysham. &rdquo;</p> <p>Chester Zoo recognises that conservation is as important here in Britain as it is elsewhere, and works with many partners on UK conservation projects. Biodiversity Officer Sarah Bird says, &ldquo;We are excited to be able to support this project financially and particularly thrilled to be able to use zoo expertise and facilities to help restore Large Heath butterflies to Heysham Moss. It has been fascinating to follow the life cycle of this rare butterfly at Chester Zoo and we are thrilled that the pupae we have so carefully reared are now hatching at Heysham Moss, their new home. Good luck butterflies!&rdquo;</p> <p>The captive breeding programme began in 2013, when a small number of adult females from the donor site at Winmarleigh, which stills supports a healthy population, were taken to Chester Zoo. Under the guidance of experts at the Zoo, these butterflies have been bred under controlled conditions throughout their life cycle, and are now being released as adult butterflies onto Heysham Moss.</p> <p>Since the Trust purchased Heysham Moss in 2004 extensive habitat management work has been undertaken, and the habitat is now considered sufficient to support a population of the Large Heath butterfly.  The two main requirements are tussocks of Hare&rsquo;s Tail Cotton Grass Eriophorum vaginatum; the larval foodplant, and Cross-leaved Heath Erica tetralix; the main nectar source.  Both are present in sufficient quantities, and recent land management work undertaken last winter will provide further areas for both plants to prosper.</p> <p>The project will continue with a further year of captive breeding, and a second release phase onto the reserve at Heysham Moss in 2015.</p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <p><strong>The Wildlife Trust for Lancashire, Manchester and North Merseyside is dedicated to the protection and promotion of the wildlife in Lancashire, seven boroughs of Greater Manchester and four of Merseyside, all lying north of the River Mersey.  It manages around 40 nature reserves and 20 Local Nature Reserves covering acres of woodland, wetland, upland and meadow. The Trust has 23,000 members, and over 1,200 volunteers.</strong></p> <p><strong>To become a member of the Trust go to the website at www.lancswt.org.uk or call 01772 324129.</strong></p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <p><strong>Lancashire Environmental Fund</strong></p> <p>The Lancashire Environmental Fund (LEF) is a partnership between SITA UK Ltd, Lancashire County Council, The Wildlife Trust for Lancashire, Manchester and North Merseyside and Community Futures.  <br /> The Fund has distributed over &pound;17m of Landfill Communities Fund support to community and environmental projects which benefit the environment and people of Lancashire since its start in 1998 with donations from SITA UK Ltd and Neales Waste Management Ltd together with a contribution from Lancashire County Council. <br /> Community and environmental groups can apply for awards from &pound;3,000 to &pound;40,000. Projects to date have included improvements to community facilities, environmental education, general environmental improvements, creation and management of habitats, improvements to parks, gardens, open spaces, play areas, recreational facilities, ponds, canals and rivers and biodiversity. Groups can apply online at www.lancsenvfund.org.uk </p> <p>For further information about Lancashire Environmental Fund contact:</p> <p>Anne Kingston, Communications Officer, at LEF on 01772 317248 or mobile 07843 079574 or e mail annekingston@lancsenvfund.org.uk or visit  www.lancsenvfund.org.uk</p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <p><strong>Chester Zoo</strong></p> <p>Chester Zoo is a registered conservation charity that supports projects around the world and in the UK. Welcoming 1.4 million visitors a year, it is the largest zoo in the UK; home to 11,000 animals, over 400 different species, many of which are endangered.</p> <p>Through its wildlife conservation campaign, Act for Wildlife, the zoo is helping to save highly threatened species around the world from extinction. Find out more at <a href="www.actforwildlife.org.uk">www.actforwildlife.org.uk</a></p> <p>For more please contact Will Condliffe via <a href="mailto:w.condliffe@chesterzoo.org">w.condliffe@chesterzoo.org</a> / 07557 744092<br /> &nbsp;</p></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:03 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{5C0E6D67-2485-4ED6-9356-FDA8321C32BB}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/dental-health-study-helps-wild-orangutans</link><title>How orangutans at Chester Zoo are helping orangutans in Indonesia and Malaysia just by opening their mouths!</title><description><p><img style="width: 495px; height: 720px;" alt="Bornean orangutan - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/orangutan-dental/OrangUtans-4.ashx" />&nbsp;</p> <p class="intro-first">A study on the dental health of orangutans at Chester Zoo could play an essential role in protecting their wild counterparts thousands of miles away in Borneo and Sumatra. </p> <p>In a bid to help vets in Malaysia and Indonesia, keepers at the Cheshire zoo are gathering new information on the emergence of teeth in their young orangutans. </p> <p>The research is helping to improve age estimations of orangutans observed in the wild and orphaned orangutans in rehabilitation facilities in South East Asia, whose dates of birth are usually unknown.</p> <p>Chester Zoo vet Steve Unwin, who also leads the Orangutan Veterinary Advisory Group (OVAG), a community of mostly Malaysian and Indonesia vets working in rehabilitation centres in those regions, said: </p> <p><strong>&ldquo;An orangutan is reliant on its mum for the first eight years of its life. But it&rsquo;s very, very difficult indeed to tell the ages of young orangutans. So, if a rehabilitated youngster is thought to be eight years old but is actually only five, this can potentially affect its chances of survival when it&rsquo;s reintroduced into the forest. </strong></p> <strong> </strong> <p><strong>&ldquo;That&rsquo;s where dental emergence studies on zoo-based orangutans which, we of course know the dates of birth of, could be highly relevant for improved age assignment of confiscated orphans in Indonesia and Malaysia. </strong></p> <strong> </strong> <p><strong>&ldquo;This is an excellent example of how zoos, and captive populations of species, can aid conservation efforts in the wild.&rdquo;</strong></p> <p>Keepers at the zoo are now busy recording when first teeth start to appear before they later wobble and fall out. </p> <p><strong>&ldquo;Whereas most people don&rsquo;t tend to look forward to a trip to the dentist, our orangutans seem to really like having their teeth checked,&rdquo; </strong>said primate keeper Kate Brice. </p> <p><strong>&ldquo;That&rsquo;s because to encourage them to open nice and wide we often use honey which we smear on a surface for them to lick off. As soon as they come over we then have to take a photograph of the insides of their mouths as quick as we can, as before you know it the honey is gone! </strong></p> <strong> </strong> <p><strong>&ldquo;Currently we&rsquo;re monitoring baby tooth timings for our two young Sumatran orangutans - Tripa and Tuti - who are both just over one year old. We first saw signs of teeth when they reached five months.</strong></p> <strong> </strong> <p><strong>&ldquo;We know orangutans have 20 baby teeth and 32 permanent adult teeth but what we need answers to in particular is whether or not timings relating to the development of permanent incisors, canines and premolars is different in males and females and between Sumatran and Bornean species of orangutans.&rdquo;</strong></p> <p>Felcity Oram, programme development advisor and PhD student with the orangutan research unit of Chester&rsquo;s Zoo&rsquo;s partner in the field &ndash; Hutan/Kinabatangan Orangutan Conservation Programme (KOCP), added: </p> <p><strong>&ldquo;Better understanding of basic life history is important in order to ensure the continued viability of orangutans in the wild, especially as they increasingly live in human-transformed landscapes.&rdquo;</strong></p> <p>Orangutans - or old man of the forest as they are also known - are one of human&rsquo;s closest relatives. But in the wild the demand for timber, palm oil, roads, agricultural land and space for mining means huge areas of forest have now been lost, taking with it the homes of both Bornean and Sumatran orangutans and pushing them perilously close to extinction.</p> <p>In October, Chester Zoo is launching a campaign to help further protect orangutans in the wild. Go Orange for Orangutans will urge schools, families, businesses and individuals to help do their bit to save the critically endangered animals. All funds raised through the campaign will help conservationists continue their work to protect orangutans in the forests of Borneo and Sumatra. Visit the zoo&rsquo;s conservation website <a href="www.actforwildlife.org.uk/orange">www.actforwildlife.org.uk/orange</a> to find out more.</p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <p><img src="/~/media/news/2014/orangutan-dental/OrangUtans-1.ashx" alt="Orangutan dental health" /></p> <p style="text-align: center;"><em>&nbsp;Sumatran orangutan Tripa shows off his baby teeth</em></p> <p style="text-align: center;"><em><br /> </em></p> <p><img alt="Orangutan dental health - Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/news/2014/orangutan-dental/OrangUtans-10.ashx" /></p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <h2>Notes to editors</h2> <p>&bull; Orangutans (and humans) only get one set of molars but two sets of premolars<br /> &bull; Orangutan dental emergence is markedly slower than in chimpanzees and more closely parallels humans<br /> &bull; They have 32 permanent adult teeth<br /> &bull; They have 20 baby (deciduous) teeth<br /> &bull; New data for tooth emergence is urgently required in four-15 year-olds as permanent teeth emergence timings are especially data deficient. Chester Zoos orangutans in this age range are therefore important participants in this study. This age range is a very important time in the life of a free ranging orangutans, whether a rehabilitant or in the wild, as it is a time of marked growth and developmental change. Better age estimation of animals in this age range could be critical to their survival chances in the wild of a rehabilitant and aid in our understanding of normal maturation in the wild<br /> &bull; New data is also needed as regards baby or deciduous teeth emergence timings, especially to see if Sumatran and Bornean are different<br /> &bull; Zoo-based orangutans can therefore supply some key information to help their fellows living in Malaysia and Indonesia both in the wild and orphan rehabilitants<br /> &bull; Chester Zoo currently has 10 Sumatran and 10 Bornean orangutans (including four which are from Blackpool Zoo who are being looked after whilst their home is being refurbished)<br /> &bull; Sumatran orangutans are critically endangered and could become the first great ape to become extinct in the wild. Borneans are also critically endangered<br /> &bull; Chester Zoo is home to the oldest orangutan in the UK, Martha, who arrived in 1965<br /> &bull; Orangutans are the only non-African great ape</p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <h2>About Chester Zoo</h2> <p>Chester Zoo (<a href="www.chesterzoo.org">www.chesterzoo.org</a>) is a registered conservation charity that supports projects around the world and closer to home in Cheshire. Welcoming 1.4 million visitors a year, it is the largest zoo in the UK; home to 11,000 animals, 400 different species, many of which are endangered.<br /> <br /> </p></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:03 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{C517FECF-F484-4915-B843-9AAA698FA999}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/bbc-gardeners-question-time</link><title>BBC Radio 4\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Gardeners\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Question Time with Chester Zoo</title><description><p>On Monday 14th July, BBC Radio 4\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Gardeners\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Question Time records a programme at Chester Zoo.</p><p>The celebrated panel of gardening experts will be tackling the questions put to them by local gardening enthusiasts, with Eric Robson in the chair. </p> <p>Gardeners&rsquo; Question Time is a Radio 4 institution, attracting over 2 million listeners a week. Recorded in a different location each week, this long-standing radio programme has answered well over 30,000 questions since its inception in 1947. </p> <p>The panel members have been guests of a diverse range of gardening clubs and other organisations; including a telecommunications call centre and the London Transport Museum. </p> <p>The panel NEVER see the questions before the recording. Their encyclopaedic, seemingly effortless answers are completely spontaneous and reveal their huge experience and depth of gardening knowledge. Being on the GQT panel is not for the faint hearted! </p> <p>Tickets cost &pound;4.50 and can be <a href="https://www.chesterzoo.org/shop/ZooEvents/bbcgardenersquestiontime.aspx">purchased online here</a> or in person via guest services, Diamond Jubilee Quarter, Chester Zoo.</p></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:03 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{287E852B-20DD-426E-91CD-DD8E18038A1A}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/warthogs-born</link><title>Warthogs born for the first time at Chester Zoo</title><description><p>Two warthogs have been born at Chester Zoo. </p><p><img alt="Warthogs born at Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/hoofed-animals/warthogs/Warthogs-5.ashx" /></p> <p>The as yet unnamed newcomers are the first of their kind to be born at the zoo.</p> <p>The piglets, who stand at just 30cm tall, arrived to first time parents Tamzin and Magnum. </p> <p>Curator of mammals, Tim Rowlands, said:</p> <p>&ldquo;This is the zoo&rsquo;s first ever warthog family and so of course we&rsquo;re absolutely thrilled.</p> <p>&ldquo;Our tiny piglets are almost hairless, wrinkly and grey and already have their trademark protruding warts from which they get their name. Some may not consider them to be as &lsquo;cute&rsquo; as many of the other babies we&rsquo;ve had born here of late, but to us, they&rsquo;re just as special.</p> <p>&ldquo;Tamzin is a protective mother and is doing a good job of shielding her youngsters so far. But the new family is becoming increasingly confident and we&rsquo;re sure they&rsquo;ll soon be hogging lots of attention.&rdquo; </p> <p><img src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/hoofed-animals/warthogs/Warthogs-9.ashx" alt="Warthog piglet" /></p> <p>Conservation charity Chester Zoo is part of a European breeding programme for the species, which arrived in Cheshire 10 years ago.</p> <p>Warthogs are wild pigs native to Africa and known for their large upward curving tusks and wart-like growths on the sides of their heads. They live up to 15 years and can grow as large as 113kg. </p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <h2>Warthog facts </h2> <p>&bull; Warthogs have one or two pairs of warts on their face beneath the eyes and near the tusks </p> <p>&bull; Males are larger than females but both sexes have upper and lower tusks </p> <p>&bull; They feed mainly on grass, roots, bark, fruit and berries but will sometimes eat insects, worms and dead animals </p> <p>&bull; Warthogs are found in sub-Saharan Africa </p> <p>&bull; They are active in the day and hide away at night, most often in burrows that have been made by aardvarks </p> <p>&bull; Mother warthogs nurse and care for their offspring until they are about 21 weeks of age, at which point they have to fend for themselves </p> <p>&bull; Chester Zoo&rsquo;s new youngsters were born on 2/5/2014 </p> <p>&bull; They can be seen in the zoo&rsquo;s Tsavo exhibit, near its Diamond Jubilee Quarter </p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <img alt="Warthog at Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/hoofed-animals/warthogs/Warthogs-1.ashx" /> <p style="text-align: center;"><em>Proud father, Magnum</em></p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <img src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/hoofed-animals/warthogs/Warthogs-3.ashx" alt="Warthog piglets born at Chester Zoo" /></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:03 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{52E3C717-44B8-4B9B-B691-46B8B68D852A}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/rare-visayan-warty-piglet-born</link><title>Chester Zoo celebrates birth of rare Visayan warty piglet</title><description><p>An extremely rare piglet has been born at Chester Zoo.</p><p><img alt="Visayan warty piglet" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/hoofed-animals/visayan-warty-pig/WartyPig-14.ashx" /> </p> <p style="text-align: center;"> <em>A rare, week-old warty piglet peeps out from between the legs of its mum Viv after being born at Chester Zoo &nbsp;</em></p> <p>Only 200 Visayan warty pigs are thought to be left in their native habitat in the Philippines &ndash; making them the rarest of all wild pigs. </p> <p>The decline of the species - almost to the point of extinction - is blamed on habitat loss and hunting. </p> <p>Keeper Lucy Edwards said: </p> <p>&ldquo;Visayan warty pigs are critically endangered and face an extremely high risk of becoming extinct in the wild. </p> <p>&ldquo;They&rsquo;ve suffered a drastic population crash in recent times with widespread commercial logging, illegal logging and agricultural expansion devastating vast amounts of their natural habitat. They&rsquo;re also being over-hunted and their meat can often command at least double the price of domestic pork in local markets and some restaurants. </p> <p>&ldquo;It really is a battle against time to save them.&rdquo; </p> <p>Chester Zoo was the first in the UK to welcome Visayan warty pigs, a species that gets its name from three pairs of fleshy warts on the boar's face. The warts protect them from rival pigs' tusks during a fight. </p> <p>The sex of the zoo&rsquo;s latest youngster &ndash; which was born to mum Viv (8) and dad Sid (7) - is still unknown. It currently sports yellow and brown stripes which act as camouflage but these will eventually disappear at around 9-12 months. </p> <p><img alt="Visayan warty piglet at Chester Zoo" src="/~/media/Images/Animals/Mammals/hoofed-animals/visayan-warty-pig/WartyPig-12.ashx" />&nbsp;</p> <p>Lucy added: </p> <p>&ldquo;Given that warty pigs have a spiky, almost mohawk-like hair style on their heads, mum Viv and dad Sid were named after punk rockers &ndash; Vivienne Westwood and Sid Vicious. Once we discover the gender of our new little addition I&rsquo;m sure we&rsquo;ll be giving him or her a name to follow in that tradition.&rdquo; </p> <p>Next spring the zoo&rsquo;s new Islands development &ndash; a &pound;30m expansion which aims to showcase its conservation work in South East Asia &ndash; will open. Islands will feature mini-replicas of several islands including the Philippines and aims to further champion the plight of species such as the Visayan warty pig. </p> <p>The zoo provides financial assistance for an education and breeding programme in the Philippines and is also working with other European zoos to ensure the survival of the pigs. </p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <h2>Visayan warty pig facts </h2> <p>&bull; The Visayan warty pig is a small, forest-dwelling pig <br /> &bull; Little is known about the species and few behavioural studies have occurred in the wild <br /> &bull; They stay in small groups but often males will be alone <br /> &bull; Male Visayan warty pigs have tough spikey hair with an unusual looking mane and crest <br /> &bull; Visayan warty pigs eat roots, forest fruits, cereal and vegetable crops <br /> &bull; They are found in patches of the remaining rainforest on the Visayan islands in the central Philippines <br /> &bull; Chester Zoo&rsquo;s latest arrival is vitally important to the breeding programme which is looking to maintain a genetically viable population of Visayan warty pigs in zoos around Europe </p></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:03 Z</pubDate></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{7E571350-A0CD-45ED-8CEC-62D884AE0F32}</guid><link>http://www.chesterzoo.org/global/press-and-media/press-releases/nature-reserve-opening</link><title>Zoo branches out to boost wildlife</title><description><p>A WILDLIFE haven specially created to help UK native species has opened at Chester Zoo.</p><p><img src="/~/media/Images/Must sees/nature-reserve/nature-reserve640x412.ashx" alt="Nature reserve" style="width: 495px; height: 319px;" /></p> <p>The two-acre nature reserve highlights a traditional Cheshire landscape and is already home to a wide variety of local wildlife including birds, mammals and insects. </p> <p>The reserve has been developed with wildflower meadows, 150 native trees, a wildlife pond and a grass amphitheatre which will be used for environmentally-themed events and as an outside classroom for schools. </p> <p>Sarah Bird, Chester Zoo&rsquo;s biodiversity officer, said: </p> <p>&ldquo;Chester Zoo&rsquo;s conservation activities extend far beyond the zoo animals we know and love. We believe conservation begins at home and in the UK we are responsible for looking after native species right here on our doorstep. The nature reserve is already home to some amazing species such as the sparrowhawk which our experts have spotted, and the hedgehog we&rsquo;ve caught on camera traps. </p> <p>&ldquo;By opening up this beautiful and tranquil area to the public we aim to inspire people to take a longer look at the nature around them and discover how they can play their part in looking after it.&rdquo; </p> <p><img src="/~/media/Images/Must sees/nature-reserve/KFP_9686.ashx" alt="School children in the Nature Reserve" /></p> <p>Youngsters from Acresfield Primary School, Upton, were the first to try out the nature reserve during the opening as they take part helping to identify bugs and insects. </p> <p>Chester Zoo trustee and horticulture expert Professor Stefan Buczacki, who spent 12 years a panel member and chairman of BBC Radio 4&rsquo;s Gardeners&rsquo; Question Time, opened the site. </p> <p>The nature reserve will be open during normal zoo hours &ndash; www.chesterzoo.org for details. It will be free of charge and accessible to the public without them having to enter the zoo.</p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <p><img src="/~/media/Images/Must sees/nature-reserve/KFP_9648.ashx" alt="Dr Mark Pilgrim, Rebecca Burke-Sharples and Professor Stefan Buczacki" /></p> <p style="text-align: center;">Professor Stefan Buczacki, Chester Zoo trustee Rebecca Burke-Sharples and Chester Zoo's director general Dr Mark Pilgrim opened the nature reserve</p></description><pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 09:58:03 Z</pubDate></item></channel></rss>
